Case Name: Amarendra Komalam Vs. Usha Sinha
Issue Presented: Whether the principle of res judicata bars re-litigation of a settled issue.
Facts of the Case: A legal dispute regarding the enforceability of a lease renewal clause and whether a previously decided issue can be reopened.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the respondent, permitting reconsideration of the issue.
Argument: The petitioner asserts that re-litigation is impermissible under Order 7, Rule 11 of CPC and the doctrine of estoppel.
Statute: Principles of Res Judicata under CPC.
Rules: Rejection of plaint.; Order 7, Rule 11 of CPC.
Precedent: S.L.P.(C) No. 16513 of 2001 – Affirming non-re-litigation of settled issues.
Ratio of the Decision: A settled issue cannot be re-agitated, as it would contradict the principle of finality in litigation.
Ruling: The Supreme Court dismissed the respondent's claim, reaffirming res judicata and estoppel.

Case Name: Karnataka Rare Earth Vs. The Senior Geologist
Respondent: Senior Geologist, Department of Mines and Geology, Karnataka
Issue Presented: Whether the denial of mining lease renewal was justified under environmental and statutory regulations.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner’s mining lease was up for renewal.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the government’s decision, emphasizing environmental protection.
Argument: The petitioner contends that the rejection was arbitrary, lacking proper justification.
Rules: Rule 24A of Mineral Concession Rules, 1960.
Precedent: Judicial precedents on the discretionary powers of the government in mining lease approvals and rejections.
Ratio of the Decision: Sustainable development principles and environmental.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the state’s discretion.

Case Name: Rajesh Kumar and Ors Vs. Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax and Ors
Respondent: Deputy Commissioner of Income Tax and Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the special audit order issued under Section 142(2A) of the Income Tax Act.
Facts of the Case: Search and seizure operations were conducted at the petitioner’s premises. Based on the seized documents, the Assessing Officer directed a special audit.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal (ITAT) ruled that the special audit was justified.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the special audit order was arbitrary, lacked proper reasoning.
Rules: Section 142(2A) of the Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Judicial precedents on the requirement of a reasoned order before imposing a special audit.
Ratio of the Decision: The absence of adequate reasoning in the special audit order rendered it legally unsustainable.
Ruling: The Supreme Court quashed the special audit order, emphasizing the necessity of proper justification.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Surjit Singh
Issue Presented: Equal pay for equal work for daily wage employees.
Facts of the Case: Daily wage workers claimed wage parity with regular staff.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the employees.
Argument: State contended that irregular hiring negates the claim for equal pay.
Statute: Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution of India.
Rules: Punjab Service Rules apply.
Precedent: Ranbir Singh vs. State of Haryana.
Ratio of the Decision: Continuous work warrants a minimum pay scale.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the ruling.

Case Name: Bengal Enamel Works Ltd Vs. Commissioner of Income-Tax, West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether technical advisor fees tied to profit share qualify as a deductible expense.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner engaged a technical advisor whose fee was a profit-linked remuneration, prompting the tax authority to challenge its reasonableness.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower tribunal disallowed the deduction, ruling the remuneration excessive under the Income Tax Act.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that the fee was reasonable given the advisor’s expertise, while the authorities contended it was excessive.
Rules: Section 40A(2) of the Income Tax Act.
Precedent: Established Supreme Court rulings on the reasonableness of claimed expenses under tax provisions.
Ratio of the Decision: The remuneration was deemed excessive relative to the service provided.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the tax authority’s decision, setting aside the deduction.

Case Name: Delhi Development Authority Vs. Skipper Construction Co. Pvt. Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether fraudulent misrepresentation in property sales violates consumer rights.
Facts of the Case: The respondent received funds from buyers despite lacking proper legal authority to sell the property.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court sided with buyers, mandating a refund to consumers.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that the respondent's actions constituted deceptive practices under urban and consumer law.
Rules: Applicable Real Estate Development Rules.
Precedent: Established Supreme Court rulings affirming consumer fraud in real estate transactions.
Ratio of the Decision: The court found that fraudulent and unethical practices by the respondent imposed liability under consumer law.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld refunds for buyers and imposed penalties on the respondent for fraudulent misrepresentation.

Case Name: Union of India Vs. R. Gandhi
Issue Presented: Whether the establishment of NCLT and NCLAT is constitutionally valid.
Facts of the Case: The creation of NCLT/NCLAT was contested on constitutional grounds.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the tribunals’ validity while recommending changes in appointment procedures.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that the tribunals were set up following the constitutional framework.
Rules: Rules governing tribunal appointments under the Companies Act.
Precedent: Prior decisions on tribunal independence and the separation of powers.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision rests on ensuring that tribunals operate independently within constitutional limits.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the validity of NCLT while mandating amendments in the appointment process.

Case Name: Lalita Kumari Vs. Government of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether failure to register an FIR in a cognizable case violates fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: An FIR was not registered by the police despite the reporting of a cognizable offense, prompting a legal challenge.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the principle that an FIR must be registered in all cognizable cases.
Argument: The petitioner contended that non-registration of an FIR undermines the right to legal protection under the Constitution.
Rules: Section 154 of the CrPC, mandating FIR registration for cognizable offenses.
Precedent: Established Supreme Court precedents affirming mandatory FIR registration in cognizable cases.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision is based on the principle that a delay or failure to register an FIR in cognizable cases breaches legal duty.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed mandatory FIR registration, ensuring police accountability in handling cognizable offenses.

Case Name: Shreya Singhal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 66A of the IT Act violates the right to freedom of speech.
Facts of the Case: Section 66A was criticized for its vague wording, leading to arbitrary restrictions on online expression.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the law was essential for maintaining order in cyberspace.
Argument: The petitioner contended that Section 66A's ambiguity resulted in excessive and unjustified censorship of online speech.
Rules: Section 66A, which criminalized online speech deemed "offensive" or "annoying".
Precedent: Established Supreme Court rulings on the necessity of precision in laws limiting fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Laws restricting free speech must be clear, precise, and meet constitutional standards.
Ruling: The Supreme Court declared Section 66A unconstitutional for violating.

Case Name: Vishaka & Ors Vs. State of Rajasthan
Issue Presented: Establishing judicial guidelines to prevent workplace sexual harassment.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed by Vishaka & Ors following an incident of sexual harassment at the workplace, demanding remedial guidelines.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court dismissed the plea on the grounds of inadequate statutory backing.
Argument: The petitioner contended that even without comprehensive legislation, the state has a constitutional duty to safeguard workplace rights.
Rules: Consideration of emerging judicial norms for preventing workplace harassment.
Precedent: Absence of a statutory framework prior to this landmark decision.
Ratio of the Decision: The court held that protecting employees from sexual harassment is a constitutional mandate that requires clear guidelines.
Ruling: The Supreme Court issued the Vishaka Guidelines, mandating measures to protect employees from sexual harassment.

Case Name: Aruna Shanbaug Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether passive euthanasia is legally permissible under strict guidelines.
Facts of the Case: A prolonged vegetative state case led to a plea for withdrawal of life support, questioning the legality of passive euthanasia.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court rejected the plea for passive euthanasia.
Argument: The petitioner contended that continued treatment in a vegetative state infringes on human dignity and rights.
Rules: Guidelines provided by medical board review regarding passive euthanasia.
Precedent: Prior to this case, there was no direct judicial ruling on euthanasia.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court held that passive euthanasia is permissible if carried out under regulated.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ultimately permitted passive euthanasia under carefully defined guidelines.

Case Name: Navtej Singh Johar Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 377 IPC, which criminalizes consensual same-sex relationships, violates constitutional freedoms.
Facts of the Case: LGBTQ+ petitioners argued that criminalizing consensual sexual conduct infringes on dignity, equality, and privacy.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court decriminalized Section 377, but Supreme Court later overturned it.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that Section 377 infringes upon the fundamental rights of LGBTQ+ individuals.
Rules: Emphasis on constitutional guarantees of privacy, equality, and dignity.
Precedent: Prior judicial decisions affirming individual rights and privacy in matters of personal conduct.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision was based on the principle that criminalizing consensual private conduct infringes.
Ruling: The Supreme Court struck down Section 377, thereby decriminalizing consensual same-sex relationships.

Case Name: Maneka Gandhi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the right to travel abroad is part of the right to personal liberty.
Facts of the Case: The petitionerâ€™s passport was impounded without giving her a valid reason, raising concerns over personal liberty.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the government decision.
Argument: Petitioner contended that the action violated Article 21 and the principles of natural justice.
Rules: Passports Act, 1967.
Precedent: Prior judicial decisions mandate that any curtailment of personal liberty must be substantiated.
Ratio of the Decision: Any law restricting personal liberty must follow the principles of fairness and due process.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the petitioner, expanding the scope of Article 21.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether industries should be held absolutely liable for environmental hazards and industrial disasters.
Facts of the Case: A factory’s oleum gas leakage raised serious issues of corporate accountability and environmental safety.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court imposed fines against the company for environmental violations.
Argument: The petitioner demanded enhanced regulatory oversight and greater corporate accountability for environmental harm.
Rules: Emphasis on strict and absolute liability principles in environmental jurisprudence.
Precedent: Citing precedents such as the Bhopal Gas Tragedy case rulings.
Ratio of the Decision: Industries engaged in hazardous activities are subject to absolute liability, regardless of fault.
Ruling: Supreme Court introduced the â€˜absolute liabilityâ€™ principle for environmental hazards.

Case Name: Olga Tellis Vs. Bombay Municipal Corporation
Issue Presented: Whether forced eviction without providing alternatives violates the right to life and livelihood under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: Eviction orders against slum dwellers were contested on the grounds that they would deprive residents.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the eviction orders based on existing municipal regulations.
Argument: The petitioner contended that compulsory eviction without reasonable alternatives infringes upon the constitutional right to shelter and livelihood.
Rules: Municipal regulations governing encroachment must be balanced against fundamental rights.
Precedent: Prior judicial decisions emphasized that the right to livelihood.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision rests on the principle that, before eviction.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that eviction cannot be enforced without ensuring adequate rehabilitation measures for affected residents.

Case Name: Indra Sawhney Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether OBC reservations are constitutional when the 'creamy layer' is excluded to ensure fairness.
Facts of the Case: The case involved a challenge to the 27% reservation for OBCs, arguing that overextension of reservation violates equality.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court endorsed the reservation policy, subject to modifications.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that reservation beyond a certain limit undermines equality.
Rules: Reservation guidelines require that the benefits be limited by excluding the 'creamy layer'.
Precedent: Prior decisions on affirmative action stress that reservations must be balanced to maintain fairness.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision was based on the principle that reservations are constitutional only if the 'creamy layer' is excluded to ensure equal opportunity.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed OBC reservations, mandating the exclusion of the 'creamy layer' to preserve fairness.

Case Name: Minerva Mills Ltd. Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether constitutional amendments can validly balance Directive Principles against Fundamental Rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged constitutional amendments on the ground that they undermined the basic structure doctrine.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the amendments.
Argument: The petitioner contended that amendments that impair or nullify Fundamental Rights are unconstitutional.
Rules: The judicial doctrine from Kesavananda Bharati that asserts the inviolability of the Constitution’s basic structure.
Precedent: Kesavananda Bharati Vs. State of Kerala.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision was based on the principle that the Directive Principles of State Policy cannot supersede Fundamental Rights.
Ruling: The Supreme Court invalidated portions of the amendment.

Case Name: ADM Jabalpur Vs. Shivkant Shukla
Issue Presented: Whether the suspension of fundamental rights under the Emergency provisions is constitutionally valid.
Facts of the Case: During the Emergency period (1975–77), detentions without trial raised profound issues regarding the protection of life and liberty.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of upholding detainees’ rights.
Argument: The petitioner contended that, under Article 359, the State possesses overriding power during an Emergency.
Rules: The emergency provisions authorize the State to curtail certain rights.
Precedent: Judicial precedents at the time supported extensive state authority during Emergency.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision rested on the doctrine that during an Emergency, the State’s power to suspend rights may supersede individual liberties.
Ruling: The Supreme Court initially upheld the suspension of fundamental rights during the Emergency.

Case Name: Kesavananda Bharati Vs. State of Kerala
Issue Presented: Whether Parliament’s power under Article 368 is subject to limitations by the basic structure doctrine.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner disputed constitutional amendments affecting fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court validated the land reform laws without addressing the constitutional amendment issue.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that amendments undermining the Constitution’s core structure are impermissible.
Rules: The basic structure doctrine limits the power of constitutional amendments.
Precedent: No prior case had clearly set limits on Parliament’s power until this decision.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment establishes that while Parliament may amend the Constitution, it cannot change its fundamental framework.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the basic structure doctrine, thereby constraining Parliament’s amendment power.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India (Taj Trapezium Case)
Issue Presented: Whether industrial pollution jeopardizing the Taj Mahal mandates stringent regulatory measures.
Facts of the Case: Pollution from nearby industries threatened the monument's integrity, leading to legal intervention.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court mandated pollution-control measures by industries.
Argument: Petitioner contended that relocating polluting industries is necessary to safeguard the Taj Mahal.
Rules: Air and Water Pollution Control Rules.
Precedent: Prior rulings on environmental protection and heritage conservation.
Ratio of the Decision: Historic monuments require robust protection from environmental hazards.
Ruling: Supreme Court ordered the relocation of polluting industries to protect the Taj Mahal.

Case Name: DK Basu Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether mandatory safeguards should be imposed to protect arrested individuals from custodial abuse.
Facts of the Case: A series of custodial torture incidents and deaths spurred the filing of a PIL for stronger arrest and detention safeguards.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court proposed guidelines to ensure the safety of detainees.
Argument: The petitioner contended that without statutory safeguards, arrests and detention practices would continue to violate human rights.
Rules: Guidelines governing arrest and detention procedures must protect the rights of detainees.
Precedent: Prior rulings have stressed that protecting fundamental rights during custody is essential for human rights accountability.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision is based on the principle that arrested individuals must be safeguarded against abuse under constitutional law.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated comprehensive guidelines to protect detainees during arrest and custody.

Case Name: Lily Thomas Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether convicted legislators should be immediately disqualified under the Representation of the People Act.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that Section 8(4) permitted convicted legislators to remain in office during appeal, thereby compromising political accountability.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the provision, maintaining that convicted legislators could continue in office pending appeal.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that immediate disqualification is essential to uphold democratic integrity.
Rules: Disqualification norms require that individuals convicted of offenses be removed from legislative positions without delay.
Precedent: Prior decisions on electoral reforms stress that allowing convicted legislators to remain in office undermines democratic accountability.
Ratio of the Decision: The core principle is that permitting convicted legislators to continue in office is contrary to the democratic mandate of political accountability.
Ruling: The Supreme Court invalidated Section 8(4), thereby mandating the immediate disqualification of convicted legislator.

Case Name: People Union for Civil Liberties Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether telephone tapping infringes on the right to privacy.
Facts of the Case: PUCL contended that government-sanctioned phone tapping violates privacy and fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court supported phone tapping for national security.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that phone tapping, if unregulated, infringes upon constitutional guarantees of privacy.
Rules: Rules governing surveillance and interception require strict safeguards.
Precedent: Prior decisions have stressed that any intrusion into personal privacy must be justified.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that any phone tapping must be strictly regulated to prevent misuse of surveillance powers.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated that phone tapping be subject to clear procedural safeguards to protect fundamental privacy rights.

Case Name: S. R. Bommai Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Article 356 is subject to judicial review to prevent misuse in dismissing elected state governments.
Facts of the Case: The dismissal of the Karnataka government under Article 356 raised questions about central overreach and federal balance.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court endorsed the dismissal.
Argument: The petitioner contended that misuse of Article 356 to dismiss democratically elected governments violates federal principles.
Rules: Principles of federalism and judicial oversight restrict arbitrary application.
Precedent: Judicial precedents mandate that any invocation of Article 356 must be subject to strict judicial review.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision establishes that Article 356 cannot be used arbitrarily.
Ruling: The Supreme Court imposed limitations on Article 356, ensuring that any dismissal of a state government is subject to review.

Case Name: Mohd. Ahmed Khan Vs. Shah Bano Begum
Issue Presented: Whether a divorced Muslim woman is entitled to maintenance under Section 125 of the CrPC.
Facts of the Case: Shah Bano, a 62-year-old Muslim woman, challenged her exclusion from maintenance benefits after divorce, invoking Section 125 CrPC, applicable irrespective of religious personal law.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court granted Shah Bano maintenance under Section 125 CrPC.
Argument: The petitioner contended that, under Muslim personal law, maintenance beyond the iddat period is not mandated.
Rules: Maintenance rights under Section 125 CrPC must be applied universally, irrespective of personal laws.
Precedent: Judicial precedents affirm that maintenance under Section 125 CrPC is available to divorced women regardless of religious personal law.
Ratio of the Decision: The core principle is that Section 125 CrPC guarantees maintenance to divorced women, thereby ensuring economic security.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the High Court's ruling, thereby granting Shah Bano maintenance.

Case Name: I. R. Coelho Vs. State of Tamil Nadu
Issue Presented: Whether laws in the Ninth Schedule can be reviewed by the judiciary if they infringe fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: Certain laws were included in the Ninth Schedule to protect them from judicial scrutiny, prompting challenges regarding fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court maintained that the laws in the Ninth Schedule were shielded from judicial review.
Argument: The petitioner contended that any law in the Ninth Schedule must be subject to judicial review if it violates the Constitution's basic structure.
Statute: Constitution of India, Article 31B and Ninth Schedule.
Rules: The basic structure doctrine mandates that even laws in the Ninth Schedule must conform to constitutional fundamental rights.
Precedent: Judicial precedents from Kesavananda Bharati affirm that no law.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle established is that laws shielded under the Ninth Schedule remain subject to judicial review.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that such laws must be reviewed by the judiciary and invalidated if found to violate constitutional guarantees.

Case Name: Vellore Citizens Welfare Forum Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the environmental damage caused by tanneries in Tamil Nadu necessitates applying the Polluter Pays Principle.
Facts of the Case: Tanneries were found to be contaminating water sources, leading to significant public health and environmental concerns.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court directed that affected communities receive compensation for the environmental damage caused by the tanneries.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that industries causing environmental harm should bear the cost of remediation under the Polluter Pays Principle.
Rules: The rules require that industries must internalize the cost of pollution prevention and remedial measures.
Precedent: Prior judicial decisions have underscored corporate accountability.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision is based on the principle that polluting industries should be financially liable for preventing and correcting environmental harm.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the Polluter Pays Principle, mandating both compensation for affected individuals and enhanced regulatory controls.

Case Name: Naz Foundation Vs. Government of NCT of Delhi
Issue Presented: Whether Section 377 of the IPC, by criminalizing consensual same-sex relationships, violates fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged Section 377, asserting that its application to consensual homosexual conduct infringed on constitutional freedoms.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Delhi High Court declared Section 377 unconstitutional for violating the right to life and personal liberty.
Argument: Petitioner argued that criminalizing homosexuality violated the right to privacy, dignity, and equality.
Rules: The decision hinges on the protection of fundamental Rights under Articles 14, 15, 19, and 21.
Precedent: Prior judicial decisions on personal liberty and privacy supported the challenge to Section 377.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle established is that any law criminalizing private, consensual behavior infringes on fundamental constitutional rights.
Ruling: The Supreme Court's subsequent rulings, after initially overturning the High Court decision.

Case Name: Puttaswamy Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the right to privacy is a fundamental right.
Facts of the Case: The Aadhaar scheme's collection of biometric data was contested as a violation of privacy rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court validated the Aadhaar scheme on constitutional grounds.
Argument: Petitioner argued that the right to privacy is an essential part of the right to life and personal liberty under Article 21.
Rules: Fundamental Rights and Data Protection Laws.
Precedent: Prior rulings affirming individual autonomy against unwarranted state surveillance.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle established is that privacy is a constitutionally guaranteed right.
Ruling: The Supreme Court unanimously affirmed that privacy is fundamental.

Case Name: Keshub Mahindra Vs. Union of India (Bhopal Gas Tragedy Case)
Issue Presented: Whether companies handling hazardous substances can be held absolutely liable for industrial disasters.
Facts of the Case: A catastrophic gas leak from the Union Carbide plant in Bhopal resulted in massive casualties, sparking litigation over corporate accountability.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court imposed penalties on the company while limiting criminal liability.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the tragedy resulted from an unforeseen accident rather than negligent conduct.
Rules: Corporate liability principles mandate strict accountability for hazardous activities.
Precedent: The MC Mehta case established that companies involved in hazardous activities can be held absolutely liable.
Ratio of the Decision: The core principle is that firms engaged in high-risk industrial activities must bear absolute liability for resulting harm.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held Union Carbide responsible and mandated compensation for the victims.

Case Name: Golaknath Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether Parliament’s authority under Article 368 extends to amending or curtailing fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner disputed the validity of the Seventeenth Amendment, contending that constitutional amendments cannot alter fundamental rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld Parliamentâ€™s power to amend the Constitution.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that fundamental rights are inviolable and should not be subject to amendment by Parliament.
Rules: The amendment power is subject to implied limitations to protect the core of the Constitution.
Precedent: No prior ruling restricting Parliament amendment powers.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights cannot be allowed to curtail fundamental rights.
Ruling: The Supreme Court initially held that fundamental rights were beyond amendment.

Case Name: Union Carbide Corporation Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the settlement adequately compensates the victims of the Bhopal Gas Tragedy.
Facts of the Case: A settlement of  was reached between the government and Union Carbide following the Bhopal disaster, sparking controversy.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court approved the settlement, though it encountered significant opposition from affected victims.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that the settlement reflected a fair compensation package.
Rules: Principles of absolute liability and victim compensation.
Precedent: Precedents in industrial disaster liability emphasize fair  for affected victims.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that compensation must be equitable and adequately meet the needs of the victims.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the settlement while permitting additional claims for further compensation if justified.

Case Name: Sheela Barse Vs. State of Maharashtra
Issue Presented: Whether the rights of women prisoners are adequately protected from custodial abuse.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed following reports of inhumane treatment of women prisoners in Maharashtra.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court implemented certain reforms without imposing stringent guidelines for the protection of women prisoners.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the ill-treatment of women prisoners necessitated robust safeguards and strict monitoring.
Rules: Existing guidelines governing prisoner rights must ensure comprehensive custodial safety measures.
Precedent: Referencing the DK Basu judgment on custodial violence as a benchmark for state accountability.
Ratio of the Decision: The underlying principle is that women prisoners are entitled to full protection from abuse.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated comprehensive reforms to ensure the humane treatment and protection of women prisoners.

Case Name: Bandhua Mukti Morcha Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the conditions of bonded labor violate fundamental human rights and labor welfare standards.
Facts of the Case: A Public Interest Litigation challenged the exploitation of bonded laborers under inhumane conditions.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court granted interim relief but stopped short of establishing comprehensive policy.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the exploitation inherent in bonded labor infringes on fundamental rights.
Rules: The legal framework mandates adherence to human rights.
Precedent: Judicial precedents have underscored that forced labor practices.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle established is that bonded labor practices are unconstitutional and require immediate remedial measures.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated that the government enact comprehensive policies for the rehabilitation.

Case Name: State of Karnataka Vs. Krishna Kumar
Issue Presented: Whether the state’s education policy, which denies reservations to a certain category of students, violates the right to education.
Facts of the Case: The policy was contested on the grounds that it failed to provide reservations for a specific group of students, impacting their right to education.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the students, granting the reservation claim.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that the state’s constraints justified the policy.
Rules: The legal framework requires that reservation policies in education ensure equal access and non-discrimination.
Precedent: Judicial precedents, including the Indra Sawhney case, emphasize that reservations must be fair.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that ensuring equal access to education is paramount.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated that the state adopt and implement equitable reservation policies.

Case Name: Ramesh Dalal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether convicted legislators should be immediately disqualified from holding public office.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the practice of allowing convicted legislators to continue in office while their appeal was pending.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court maintained that legislators may continue in office while their appeal is pending.
Argument: The petitioner contended that permitting convicted legislators to serve compromises democratic integrity and accountability.
Rules: Disqualification rules mandate immediate removal of convicted legislators.
Precedent: Referencing the Lily Thomas case on immediate disqualification of convicted legislators.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that convicted legislators must be removed from office immediately to safeguard democratic standards.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that once convicted, MPs and MLAs must be disqualified without delay.

Case Name: Mohini Jain Vs. State of Karnataka
Issue Presented: Whether the practice of charging high capitation fees by private medical colleges violates the right to education.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contested that exorbitant capitation fees impede access to education in private medical institutions.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court maintained that private colleges' right to charge fees.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that access to education is a constitutional right and that high capitation fees compromise equal access.
Rules: Regulatory framework governing private educational institutions.
Precedent: Precedents like the Unni Krishnan case emphasize that education is a fundamental right warranting equitable access.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision hinges on the principle that education must be universally accessible.
Ruling: The Supreme Court declared that capitation fees, as imposed, are unconstitutional and mandated reforms to protect the right to education.

Case Name: State of Maharashtra Vs. Madhukar Narayan Mardikar
Issue Presented: Whether a woman's right to privacy and dignity.
Facts of the Case: A woman, identified as a prostitute, was denied legal protection, raising concerns about gender equality and personal dignity.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of protecting her rights, emphasizing the need for equal treatment under the law.
Argument: The petitioner contended that a woman's occupation must not diminish her entitlement to constitutional protection.
Rules: The legal framework mandates that fundamental rights and protections apply equally to all women, irrespective of their profession.
Precedent: Judicial precedents affirm that equal protection under the law is essential for all women.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle established is that the right to privacy and dignity is inviolable for all women.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that all women are entitled to equal protection of their privacy and dignity, regardless of occupation.

Case Name: Jarnail Singh Vs. Lachhmi Narain Gupta
Issue Presented: Whether promotions reservation for SC/ST employees is justified without quantifiable data.
Facts of the Case: A challenge was raised regarding the validity of promotions reservation for SC/ST employees.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court rejected blanket reservations in promotions.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that reservation in promotions should be contingent upon objective data demonstrating backwardness.
Rules: Reservation policies in public employment must be supported by objective, quantifiable criteria.
Precedent: The Indra Sawhney case, which set guidelines for reservation.
Ratio of the Decision: Reservation in promotions is justified only if backed by quantifiable data demonstrating the community's backwardness.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated that promotions reservations must be based on quantifiable evidence.

Case Name: Gian Kaur Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether Section 306 IPC, criminalizing abetment of suicide, violates the right to life by implying a "right to die".
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that criminalizing abetment of suicide infringes on personal autonomy and the right to end one's life.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court invalidated Section 306 IPC on the basis that it conflicted with the petitioner's interpretation of the right to life.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that personal autonomy should include the right to die.
Rules: Fundamental rights under Article 21 must be interpreted without extending to a "right to die".
Precedent: Judicial precedents affirm that the right to life does not encompass a right to die.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that while the right to life is fundamental.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ultimately upheld Section 306 IPC, confirming that abetment of suicide is criminal and not protected by the right to life.

Case Name: K. S. Puttaswamy (Retd.) Vs. Union of India (Aadhaar Case)
Issue Presented: Whether the mandatory linking of Aadhaar infringes on the fundamental right to privacy.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that compulsory Aadhaar linkage for accessing services violates individual privacy and autonomy.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court maintained that the Aadhaar linking requirement was constitutionally acceptable.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that mandatory Aadhaar linkage constituted an arbitrary infringement on personal privacy.
Rules: Aadhaar Act, 2016.
Precedent: Judicial precedents on privacy and personal autonomy support strict scrutiny of state surveillance measures.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle established is that privacy is inviolable and cannot be compromised without compelling justification.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the constitutional validity of Aadhaar while imposing limitations on its compulsory application.

Case Name: Shayara Bano Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the practice of instant triple talaq violates constitutional guarantees of gender justice and fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contested that instant triple talaq, as applied, undermines the rights of Muslim women by being arbitrary and discriminatory.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the validity of instant triple talaq under the framework of existing Muslim personal law.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that instant triple talaq contravenes constitutional principles by denying equal protection and dignity.
Rules: The applicable statutory framework under the Muslim Personal Law.
Precedent: Judicial precedents have emphasized that any religious practice infringing on gender equality.
Ratio of the Decision: The core rationale is that instantaneous triple talaq violates the principles of equality.
Ruling: The Supreme Court invalidated the practice of instant triple talaq, ruling it unconstitutional and in violation of fundamental rights.

Case Name: Common Cause Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether individuals have the constitutional right to legalize passive euthanasia and make living wills.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued for the recognition of living wills and the legalization of passive euthanasia as a facet of personal autonomy.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court rejected the claim for legalizing passive euthanasia and living wills.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the right to die with dignity, including the refusal of artificial life support.
Rules: Regulatory guidelines for passive euthanasia and living wills.
Precedent: The Aruna Shanbaug case set important precedents regarding passive euthanasia.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that the right to life encompasses the right to die with dignity.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the right to passive euthanasia and acknowledged living wills.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Kamal Nath
Issue Presented: Whether private development projects causing river diversion and forest land encroachment violate environmental laws.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner disputed that a private resort project, involving river diversion and forest land encroachment, harmed the ecosystem.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court imposed fines on the developers yet permitted the project to proceed.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the project breached environmental laws and disrupted public resources.
Rules: The Public Trust Doctrine mandates that natural resources must be preserved for public use.
Precedent: Prior rulings have reinforced that state responsibility under the Public Trust Doctrine requires sustainable use of natural resources.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that public resources must be safeguarded against misuse.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the project violated the Public Trust Doctrine and mandated the restoration of the affected area.

Case Name: State of Tamil Nadu Vs. K. Balu
Issue Presented: Whether a ban on liquor shops within a specified distance from highways is necessary to ensure public safety.
Facts of the Case: A PIL challenged the presence of liquor shops along highways, alleging they increase the risk of accidents due to drunk driving.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court maintained the status quo on liquor licensing policies.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that unrestricted liquor sales near highways endanger public safety and require regulatory intervention.
Rules: Relevant Liquor Licensing Rules and Road Safety Regulations.
Precedent: Prior rulings emphasizing state regulatory authority over liquor sales to protect public safety.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle established is that public safety must override commercial interests in liquor regulation.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated a ban on liquor shops within 500 meters of highways to safeguard public safety.

Case Name: Delhi Transport Corporation Vs. DTC Mazdoor Congress
Issue Presented: Whether the termination of DTC employees without due process violates principles of natural justice.
Facts of the Case: Employees of the DTC were terminated arbitrarily, prompting a legal challenge based on a violation of due process.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled for the employees, ordering their reinstatement.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the termination was a matter of managerial discretion.
Rules: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Precedent: Prior rulings emphasize that termination decisions must comply with due process and natural justice.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle established is that arbitrary termination is unconstitutional without adherence to procedural fairness.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the High Court’s decision and ordered the reinstatement of the terminated employees.

Case Name: State of Uttar Pradesh Vs. Raj Narain
Issue Presented: Whether government documents affecting public interest must be disclosed under the right to information.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner demanded access to election-related government documents to enhance transparency and accountability.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ordered the disclosure of the contested documents in favor of public transparency.
Argument: The petitioner argued that certain documents were confidential and should not be made public.
Rules: The framework under Right to Information and Public Accountability Laws mandates disclosure of information affecting public interest.
Precedent: Prior judgments on freedom of information support the disclosure of government records affecting the public.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision is based on the principle that public interest outweighs confidentiality in matters of governmental transparency.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed that the right to information is a fundamental right.

Case Name: M. Nagaraj Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether reservations in promotions for SC/ST employees are constitutional, provided they are based on quantifiable data.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner disputed reservations in promotions on the grounds that they undermine merit and must be justified by data.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court maintained that the reservation policy was valid.
Argument: The petitioner contended that reservations must be objectively justified by measurable evidence of backwardness.
Rules: Reservation policies in public employment must be supported by quantifiable data to justify their extension to promotions.
Precedent: The Indra Sawhney judgment emphasizes that reservations in promotions require objective criteria.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that reservation in promotions is permissible only if supported by clear, measurable data on backwardness.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the validity of promotions reservations, directing that they be substantiated by objective data.

Case Name: Joseph Shine Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 497 IPC, which criminalizes adultery, violates gender equality and personal autonomy.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the criminalization of adultery, arguing that it violated gender equality and undermines personal autonomy.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court maintained the validity of Section 497 IPC.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that criminalizing adultery in the current form is inherently discriminatory and unconstitutional.
Rules: Fundamental rights under Articles 14, 15, and 21 must be upheld.
Precedent: Judicial precedents on gender equality and personal liberty support the challenge.
Ratio of the Decision: The principle is that a law criminalizing consensual behavior, which treats women as property.
Ruling: The Supreme Court declared Section 497 IPC unconstitutional, thereby decriminalizing adultery.

Case Name: Kartar Singh Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether TADA’s provisions violate fundamental rights by allowing extended detention without trial.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that TADA’s provisions, particularly on preventive detention, infringe upon due process rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that TADA was constitutional and necessary for national security.
Argument: The petitioner asserted that TADA’s stringent provisions arbitrarily restricted personal liberty and fair trial rights.
Rules: Fundamental rights under Articles 14 and 21 must be protected even in counterterrorism laws.
Precedent: Judicial precedents balancing counterterrorism laws with constitutional safeguards.
Ratio of the Decision: National security is a valid concern, but laws like TADA must be subject to judicial review and procedural safeguards.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld TADA but imposed safeguards to prevent its arbitrary use and ensure procedural fairness.

Case Name: Nandini Satpathy Vs. P.L. Dani
Issue Presented: Whether compelling an accused to answer police questions violates Article 20(3) of the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner refused to answer interrogation questions, claiming her right against self-incrimination under Article 20(3).
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held that refusal to answer could be interpreted as an adverse inference.
Argument: The petitioner contended that compelling answers during police questioning violates constitutional protections.
Statute: Article 20(3) of the Indian Constitution, protecting individuals from self-incrimination.
Rules: Constitutional provisions safeguarding accused individuals from forced self-incrimination.
Precedent: Judicial precedents reinforcing the right against compelled testimony.
Ratio of the Decision: Forced self-incrimination is unconstitutional, and legal protections must be upheld.
Ruling: The Supreme Court reinforced Article 20(3), protecting accused individuals from coercive interrogation tactics.

Case Name: Sarla Mudgal Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether a Hindu man can convert to Islam solely to practice polygamy without dissolving the first marriage.
Facts of the Case: A Hindu man embraced Islam for the purpose of contracting a second marriage while his first Hindu marriage remained valid.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held that under Muslim personal law, the second marriage was legally permissible.
Argument: The petitioner contended that religious conversion should not be used as a tool to evade Hindu marriage laws.
Statute: Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, which prohibits bigamy for Hindus.
Rules: Legal principles on bigamy and marriage across different religious laws.
Precedent: Judicial decisions on conflicts between personal laws and fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Religious conversion does not grant automatic exemption from prior legal obligations under personal laws.
Ruling: The Supreme Court held that a converted Muslim cannot escape liability under Hindu marriage laws for bigamy.

Case Name: Visakha Vs. State of Rajasthan
Issue Presented: Lack of legal framework for addressing workplace sexual harassment.
Facts of the Case: A woman faced workplace harassment, prompting a PIL seeking legal measures for protection.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court rejected the plea, stating that no formal law existed to address workplace sexual harassment.
Argument: The petitioner contended that fundamental rights necessitate protection against workplace harassment, even in absence of a statute.
Rules: Supreme Court’s role in developing legal norms for gender justice at workplaces.
Precedent: Lack of established jurisprudence on workplace sexual harassment before this case.
Ratio of the Decision: Protection against harassment is implicit in the fundamental right to dignity and equality.
Ruling: The Supreme Court formulated the Vishaka Guidelines, establishing mandatory workplace safety measures.

Case Name: Bachan Singh Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the death penalty violates fundamental rights under Article 21.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was sentenced to death under IPC Section 302 and challenged its constitutional validity.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the death penalty is constitutional and does not violate fundamental rights.
Argument: The petitioner claimed that capital punishment is arbitrary and infringes upon the right to life and dignity.
Rules: The principle that the death penalty should be applied only in the ‘rarest of rare’ cases.
Precedent: Earlier judgments on the constitutionality and limitations of the death penalty.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled that capital punishment is valid but must be restricted to extraordinary cases.
Ruling: The Supreme Court confirmed the legality of the death penalty but emphasized the ‘rarest of rare’ doctrine.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Dalbir Singh
Issue Presented: Whether the mandatory death penalty under the NDPS Act violates judicial discretion.
Facts of the Case: The case questioned whether imposing a mandatory death sentence under the NDPS Act is constitutional.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the mandatory death penalty under NDPS Act was valid.
Argument: The respondent argued that eliminating judicial discretion in sentencing is unconstitutional.
Rules: The principle that sentencing should allow for judicial discretion.
Precedent: Reference to Bachan Singh and ‘rarest of rare’ doctrine.
Ratio of the Decision: Courts must have discretion in sentencing to consider case-specific circumstances.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that a mandatory death penalty under the NDPS Act is unconstitutional.

Case Name: State (Delhi Administration) Vs. Vishwa Bandhu Alias Billa and Another
Respondent: Vishwa Bandhu Alias Billa and Ram Kishan Alias Phokan
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court's acquittal was legally justified based on the available evidence.
Facts of the Case: Phokan, armed with a knife, attempted to escape and called out to Billa; the High Court reversed the conviction due to insufficient evidence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court acquitted the accused, finding the evidence insufficient to establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
Argument: Argued that the evidence did not meet the standard of proof required to establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
Rules: The prosecution must prove the elements of murder beyond a reasonable doubt.
Precedent: No precedent was cited by the High Court.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court determined that sufficient evidence existed to convict the accused, thereby reversing the High Court's acquittal.
Ruling: The acquittal was overturned; both accused were convicted under Section 326 IPC and sentenced to six years of rigorous imprisonment.

Case Name: Ram Saran Dass Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the termination order, effectively a dismissal without due process, required constitutional safeguards.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was terminated and argued that the order was punitive and lacked due process.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court dismissed the petition outright.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the termination was effectively a dismissal and arbitrary, thus requiring constitutional protection under due process principles.
Rules: Service Rule 23 governing termination of employment.
Precedent: Established case law emphasizing procedural fairness and due process in dismissals.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that the principles of natural justice mandate allowing the respondent to be heard prior to dismissal of the petition.
Ruling: The Supreme Court allowed the appeal and remanded the case so that the respondent could present its case.

Case Name: Credit Agricole Indosuez Vs. Credential Finance Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the non-crediting of a cheque post-clearance justifies winding up under the Companies Act.
Facts of the Case: A banking company (petitioner) maintained the respondent's account, and the cheque amount was not credited after clearance.
Ruling by Lower Court: The petition for winding up was dismissed by the lower court.
Argument: It was argued that there were valid reasons for the cheque not being credited.
Rules: The case hinges on how judicial interpretations define cheque clearance obligations.
Precedent: Established case law regarding cheque clearance and corporate insolvency is relevant.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision centers on if the failure to credit a cheque constitutes an inability to pay debts under the legal framework.
Ruling: Appeal filed; further hearings required.

Case Name: A.K. Gopalan Vs. State of Madras
Issue Presented: Whether preventive detention under the Preventive Detention Act violates Article 21 rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged his detention under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, claiming it breached his fundamental rights under Article 21.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the validity of the Preventive Detention Act.
Argument: The petitioner contended that detention without a fair trial infringed on Article 21 protections.
Statute: The interpretation of fundamental rights under Article 21.
Rules: Fundamental Rights under Article 21.
Precedent: No specific precedent on preventive detention laws was cited.
Ratio of the Decision: Article 21 is subject to procedural laws, and preventive detention can be valid if due process is followed.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the Act’s validity, though subsequent interpretations have broadened the scope of Article 21 protections.

Case Name: State of West Bengal Vs. Anwar Ali Sarkar
Issue Presented: Whether referral to special courts violates Article 14's guarantee of equality before the law.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that the law permitting selective referral to special courts breached the right to equality.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court struck down the law as discriminatory.
Argument: It was argued that referring cases only to special courts undermines the principle of non-discrimination guaranteed by Article 14.
Rules: The principle that legal processes must be uniform and non-arbitrary.
Precedent: Prior decisions addressing the role of special courts and the requirement of non-discrimination.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized that any special court mechanism must adhere to uniform standards to ensure equality before the law.
Ruling: The Supreme Court declared the law unconstitutional for violating Article 14.

Case Name: Kedar Nath Singh Vs. State of Bihar
Issue Presented: Sedition and freedom of speech under Article 19(1)(a).
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, who criticized government policies, was convicted under Section 124A IPC (sedition).
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the sedition conviction.
Argument: The petitioner contended that sedition laws impose unreasonable restrictions on free speech.
Statute: Section 124A of the Indian Penal Code.
Rules: Free speech may be restricted reasonably under the law.
Precedent: Existing precedents on sedition and free speech.
Ratio of the Decision: Government criticism does not constitute sedition unless it incites violence.
Ruling: The Supreme Court maintained Section 124A but restricted its use to cases where the speech incites violence.

Case Name: Bharat Singh Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether the land acquisition was for a legitimate public purpose.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that the acquisition of agricultural land was not intended for a public purpose.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the acquisition.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that the acquisition violated landowners' rights by not providing fair compensation.
Rules: The acquisition must be for a legitimate public purpose.
Precedent: Established case law on land acquisition and compensation is relevant.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision confirmed that land acquisition is valid only if it serves a public purpose and ensures fair compensation.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the government’s decision while stressing the importance of fair compensation to landowners.

Case Name: Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the NJAC Act violates judicial independence by undermining the separation of powers.
Facts of the Case: The NJAC Act, 2014, was contested as it was alleged to erode the independence of the judiciary by increasing executive influence over judicial appointments.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the NJAC’s validity.
Argument: It was contended that the NJAC diluted judicial independence by interfering with the constitutional process of judicial appointments.
Rules: The constitutional framework governing judicial appointments and the separation of powers.
Precedent: Earlier case law emphasizing the principle of judicial independence and separation of powers.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling stressed that judicial independence is fundamental to the Constitution and any attempt to dilute it.
Ruling: The Supreme Court declared the NJAC unconstitutional, thereby preserving judicial independence.

Case Name: Laxmi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether stricter acid sale regulations and enhanced victim compensation are necessary to protect acid attack survivors.
Facts of the Case: A Public Interest Litigation challenged existing laws, arguing that lax regulation of acid sales led to frequent attacks and insufficient support for victims.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court recommended more rigorous enforcement of current regulations.
Argument: It was contended that unrestricted acid sales facilitate attacks and that victims need better rehabilitation and compensation measures.
Rules: Legal framework governing acid sale and provisions for victim support and rehabilitation.
Precedent: Prior decisions concerning women's safety and victim protection.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision emphasizes that enhanced regulation of acid sales and adequate victim compensation are crucial to prevent acid attacks.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of stricter acid sale regulations and improved compensation for acid attack survivors.

Case Name: Tamil Nadu Govt. Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether central laws affecting education infringe on the state’s powers over education policy.
Facts of the Case: The state argued that central laws impacting education should not interfere with state authority in education.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the central laws.
Argument: It was argued that education should primarily fall within state jurisdiction, as per constitutional provisions, despite shared responsibilities with the center.
Rules: The constitutional framework dividing subjects between the state and central governments.
Precedent: Earlier rulings addressing federalism and the respective roles of the state and central governments in education.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision confirms that while education involves concurrent jurisdiction, the central laws are valid, with states granted flexibility in their implementation.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the central laws, simultaneously allowing states to exercise discretion in how they implement education policies.

Case Name: Subramanian Swamy Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether criminal defamation laws of the IPC violate the right to free speech.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that criminal defamation laws unduly restricted free speech, as they criminalize acts that should be civil offenses.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the criminal defamation provisions in the IPC were constitutionally valid.
Argument: The petitioner argued that defamation should be treated as a civil offense, rather than a criminal one, to preserve free speech.
Rules: Protection of reputation and freedom of speech.
Precedent: Previous rulings on defamation and its limitations in the context of free speech.
Ratio of the Decision: Defamation laws are necessary to protect individual reputation, and their criminalization is a reasonable restriction on free speech.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of criminal defamation laws.

Case Name: Ram Jawaya Kapur Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the executive has the authority to act independently without legislative authorization.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contested the government's executive powers, specifically the running of businesses without legislative authorization.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the government’s action, asserting the scope of executive powers.
Argument: The petitioner claimed that the executive’s action to run a business without legislative sanction violated the doctrine of separation of powers.
Rules: Separation of powers between the legislature, executive, and judiciary.
Precedent: Previous cases on the scope and limits of executive authority under the Indian Constitution.
Ratio of the Decision: Executive powers are valid in areas not explicitly covered by legislation, but they must not contravene legislative authority.
Ruling: The Supreme Court affirmed the government’s action.

Case Name: State of Bihar Vs. K.K. Misra
Issue Presented: Whether government employees have the right to strike, especially when it involves essential services.
Facts of the Case: Government employees in Bihar went on strike demanding higher wages, resulting in disciplinary measures against them.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the strike was justified under the circumstances, allowing employees to claim rights to protest.
Argument: The respondent argued that workers have the right to strike as part of their freedom of association.
Rules: Restrictions on strikes in essential services and the rights of employees to protest or form associations.
Precedent: Earlier judgments regarding government employees' rights to protest and the limits of such rights.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to strike must be balanced with the larger public interest.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that government employees do not have the unrestricted right to strike.

Case Name: Sundararamier & Co. Vs. State of Andhra Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether a state law imposing sales tax on inter-state trade is valid under the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner contended that a state-imposed sales tax on inter-state trade violated the Constitution by infringing on Parliament's exclusive power.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the state law imposing a sales tax on inter-state trade was constitutionally valid.
Argument: The respondent argued that the state law was valid under the Constitution and complied with fiscal federalism principles.
Rules: Restrictions on state taxation powers concerning inter-state trade.
Precedent: Previous cases on fiscal federalism.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that the state law imposing sales tax on inter-state trade violated the Constitution by encroaching on Parliament's exclusive taxation powers.
Ruling: The Supreme Court struck down the state law, ruling that only Parliament has the exclusive power to tax inter-state trade.

Case Name: Golak Nath Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether Parliament has the power to amend fundamental rights under Article 368 of the Indian Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that amendments by Parliament to curtail fundamental rights were unconstitutional.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the power of Parliament to amend fundamental rights.
Argument: The respondent argued that Parliament’s power to amend the Constitution, including fundamental rights.
Rules: The doctrine of implied limitations on Parliament’s power to amend the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous rulings did not restrict Parliament's ability to amend fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that fundamental rights are beyond the power of Parliament to amend.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that fundamental rights are unamendable, but this was later overruled in the Kesavananda Bharati case.

Case Name: Shankarappa Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the government's censorship powers over films violate freedom of speech.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the Censor Board's denial of certification, claiming it infringed upon the right to free speech.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the decision of the Censor Board to deny certification.
Argument: The petitioner argued that censorship by the government violated freedom of speech.
Statute: Cinematograph Act, 1952, which governs film certification and censorship in India.
Rules: Censorship powers must be exercised reasonably and within the framework of freedom of speech regulations.
Precedent: Previous cases on the balance between free speech and reasonable censorship in media and films.
Ratio of the Decision: Censorship must be exercised based on reasonable grounds and cannot be arbitrarily imposed by the government.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that while censorship is allowed, it must not be arbitrary or infringe upon fundamental freedoms of speech.

Case Name: Madhu Limaye Vs. Sub-Divisional Magistrate
Issue Presented: Whether Section 144 CrPC, when used to curb public gatherings, infringes upon the right to freedom of speech and assembly.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the government's frequent use of Section 144 CrPC, which prohibits public gatherings, as a restriction on free speech.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the use of Section 144 CrPC by the government to maintain public order and prevent disturbances.
Argument: The petitioner argued that Section 144 was being misused to curb free speech and the right to assemble, violating fundamental rights.
Statute: Code of Criminal Procedure, which allows the government to issue orders to prevent public gatherings in certain situations.
Rules: Freedom of speech and protection of life and personal liberty.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the use of Section 144 CrPC in relation to maintaining public order and its compatibility with fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Section 144 can be invoked in specific cases of emergency, but its use must not be routine or arbitrary. It must not infringe upon fundamental freedoms.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld Section 144 but placed restrictions on its arbitrary use, emphasizing that it must be invoked in exceptional circumstances.

Case Name: Rupa Ashok Hurra Vs. Ashok Hurra
Issue Presented: Whether the Supreme Court should allow reconsideration of its judgment through a curative petition after review petitions are exhausted.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner sought a curative petition after the rejection of review petitions, claiming that a gross miscarriage of justice had occurred.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that after the exhaustion of review petitions, no further appeal or petition could be entertained.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the courts should provide a mechanism to correct serious judicial errors and prevent miscarriage of justice.
Statute: Article 137 of the Constitution, which allows the Supreme Court to review its judgments.
Rules: Judicial review and the scope of curative petitions as a mechanism for correcting judicial errors.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the finality of judgments and the limited scope for judicial review after a decision has been made.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that a curative petition can be used in exceptional cases of gross miscarriage of justice where there has been a fundamental error.
Ruling: The Supreme Court established the concept of curative petitions to allow for correction of judicial errors in rare and exceptional circumstances.

Case Name: Shyam Narayan Chouksey Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the mandatory playing of the national anthem in cinemas is required by law to promote patriotism.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner sought a directive to make the playing of the national anthem before movies mandatory.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court dismissed the petition, stating that mandating the national anthem before screenings was not legally required.
Argument: The petitioner argued that making the national anthem mandatory would promote national pride and unity among citizens.
Statute: Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971, and guidelines on national symbols.
Rules: Legal principles surrounding respect for national symbols under the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous cases regarding respect for national symbols and the constitutional framework surrounding the national anthem.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court initially made the playing of the national anthem mandatory but later reversed the decision, making it optional.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that while citizens should respect the national anthem, making it mandatory in cinemas was not a legal requirement.

Case Name: State of Kerala Vs. N.M. Thomas
Issue Presented: Whether extending reservations in promotions to SC/ST employees exceeds constitutional provisions.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the extension of reservations to promotions for SC/ST employees, contending it violated constitutional provisions on reservation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court struck down the government policy of providing reservations in promotions for SC/ST employees.
Argument: The petitioner argued that reservations should be available not only for initial appointments but also for promotions in order to uplift backward classes.
Rules: Public employment laws governing reservation policies.
Precedent: Previous cases, particularly the Indra Sawhney case, which dealt with the limits of reservation policies in public employment.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court upheld reservation in promotions under specific conditions.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the policy of reservation in promotions for SC/ST employees, but only under specific conditions justified by social justice.

Case Name: Vishwanath Vs. State of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether mere suspicion of dowry death can lead to conviction, and the shift of burden of proof in such cases.
Facts of the Case: A woman’s death under suspicious circumstances soon after her marriage prompted an investigation under dowry death laws.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court convicted the accused under Section 304B of the Indian Penal Code, relating to dowry death.
Argument: The petitioner contended that suspicion alone, without concrete evidence, should not result in a conviction under dowry death laws.
Statute: Indian Penal Code, Section 304B, pertaining to dowry death.
Rules: The Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961, which penalizes dowry-related offenses.
Precedent: Prior rulings on dowry deaths and the shifting burden of proof in such cases.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court upheld the conviction, emphasizing that in dowry death cases.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the conviction under dowry death laws but stressed that the evidence must be strong and convincing.

Case Name: MC Mehta Vs. Union of India (Ganga Pollution Case)
Issue Presented: Whether the failure to prevent pollution in the Ganga River violated the right to a clean environment.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner filed a PIL to address the severe pollution in the Ganga River caused by industrial effluents and untreated sewage.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court issued directions to control pollution but failed to enforce them strictly.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the continued pollution violated the fundamental right to a clean and healthy environment.
Rules: Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974.
Precedent: Previous rulings on environmental pollution and the state’s responsibility to protect natural resources.
Ratio of the Decision: The state has a constitutional duty to protect and maintain water bodies, and pollution laws must be enforced effectively.
Ruling: The Supreme Court mandated stricter monitoring and closure of industries polluting the Ganga River.

Case Name: Govind Vs. State of Madhya Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether police surveillance violates the petitioner’s right to privacy.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged police surveillance, claiming it was an infringement of his right to privacy.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the surveillance, citing its necessity for maintaining public order and safety.
Argument: The petitioner argued that unrestricted police surveillance was a violation of his personal liberty and right to privacy.
Rules: Right to privacy and police surveillance procedures under the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous cases on the balance between surveillance for public safety and individual privacy.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to privacy is fundamental but may be subject to reasonable restrictions.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the surveillance but called for appropriate safeguards to protect privacy from unnecessary intrusion.

Case Name: Indian Medical Association Vs. V.P. Shantha
Issue Presented: Whether medical services provided for consideration fall under the Consumer Protection Act.
Facts of the Case: The respondent filed a complaint for medical negligence, seeking compensation under the Consumer Protection Act.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court held that medical services provided for payment are subject to consumer protection laws.
Argument: The petitioner argued that doctors should not be considered service providers under the Consumer Protection Act.
Rules: The Consumer Protection Act applies to services rendered for a fee, including medical services.
Precedent: Precedents regarding the scope of services under consumer protection laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court affirmed that medical services provided for consideration fall under the Consumer Protection Act.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that medical negligence can be addressed under the Consumer Protection Act.

Case Name: People Union for Democratic Rights Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether labor laws are being enforced in construction projects, particularly during the Asiad Games construction.
Facts of the Case: A  PIL was filed to address violations of labor laws in construction projects during the Asiad Games, specifically regarding worker rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court found labor law violations but only issued advisory recommendations without enforcing strict action.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the violation of labor laws and the non-enforcement of these laws were infringing on the fundamental rights of workers.
Statute: Minimum Wages Act, 1948; Constitution of India.
Rules: Labor rights and the obligation of the state to implement labor laws effectively.
Precedent: Previous cases related to the enforcement of labor laws and the duties of the state to ensure worker protection.
Ratio of the Decision: The state has a constitutional obligation to ensure the enforcement of labor laws to protect workers' rights and ensure proper conditions.
Ruling: The Supreme Court directed the strict enforcement of labor laws, emphasizing the need to protect the fundamental rights of workers.

Case Name: Ramesh Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether a TV serial that allegedly promotes religious intolerance should be banned for violating public order and national integration.
Facts of the Case: A complaint was filed against a TV serial that was accused of spreading communal disharmony and promoting religious intolerance.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the TV serial could continue broadcasting, finding no grounds for a ban.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the content of the serial incited communal hatred and should be banned under the law.
Rules: Freedom of speech is not absolute and is subject to reasonable restrictions, including the prevention of incitement to violence.
Precedent: Previous rulings on balancing free speech with public order, media regulation, and incitement to violence.
Ratio of the Decision: Artistic freedom is protected under free speech, but content that incites violence or hatred may be restricted.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the right to broadcast, emphasizing that content should be monitored for objectionable material but not banned outright.

Case Name: Hindustan Sugar Mills Ltd. Vs. State of Rajasthan and Others
Issue Presented: Whether freight charges should be included in the taxable sale price for cement under the Cement Control Order and related tax laws.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, Hindustan Sugar Mills, sells cement within and outside Rajasthan and disputed the inclusion of freight in the taxable sale price.
