Ruling by Lower Court: Lower authorities decided that freight charges should be included in the sale price, subjecting them to tax under the applicable sales tax law.
Argument: The petitioner argued that freight charges were part of the price of the cement and should therefore be included in the taxable sale price.
Statute: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, Rajasthan Sales Tax Act, 1954.
Rules: Taxation laws relating to the definition of "sale price" under the Central and Rajasthan Sales Tax Acts.
Precedent: Previous cases interpreting the inclusion of freight charges in taxable sale prices under similar tax laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The main issue was whether freight charges could be considered part of the sale price for the purpose of taxation under the Cement Control Order.
Ruling: The case remains pending on the determination of whether freight charges should be included in the sale price for tax purposes.

Case Name: R.G. Anand Vs. Delux Films
Issue Presented: Whether there was copyright infringement by Delux Films for allegedly copying the theme, characters, and storyline from Anand's play.
Facts of the Case: R.G. Anand claimed that Delux Films' movie was based on his play, involving similarities in characters, theme, and overall expression.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled that the similarities between the play and the film were incidental, not significant enough to constitute infringement.
Argument: Anand argued that the film’s similarities in theme and expression amounted to copyright infringement, despite the lack of identical details.
Rules: The concept of substantial similarity in determining copyright infringement, specifically focusing on the level of expression copied.
Precedent: Earlier decisions on artistic originality, protection of literary works, and the concept of substantial similarity in copyright cases.
Ratio of the Decision: Copyright infringement does not occur simply because the theme is similar unless the actual expression or specific details are copied.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that broad themes and general ideas cannot be copyrighted, and the petitioner's claim of infringement was dismissed.

Case Name: Shri Roshanlal Gautam Vs. State Of Uttar Pradesh And Others
Respondent: State of Uttar Pradesh and Others
Issue Presented: Whether the Uttar Pradesh government had the authority to nationalize transport services.
Facts of the Case: Shri Roshanlal Gautam had a valid contract carriage permit for the Agra region, which was impacted by the state's decision to nationalize transport routes.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Allahabad High Court upheld the Uttar Pradesh government's decision to nationalize transport services.
Argument: Gautam argued that the state could not revoke his permit, as it interfered with his legal rights as a permit holder.
Rules: Section 68-C of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939, allowing the state to nationalize routes and revoke private operator permits.
Precedent: Previous rulings interpreting Section 68-C, particularly concerning the state's power to nationalize transport routes.
Ratio of the Decision: The case focused on whether private operators had a legal claim against the government's decision to nationalize transport services.
Ruling: Awaiting Supreme Court's verdict.

Case Name: P. Rathinam Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether Section 309 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), criminalizing attempted suicide, violates the right to life and dignity.
Facts of the Case: P. Rathinam challenged the criminalization of attempted suicide.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the constitutionality of Section 309 IPC, ruling that attempted suicide was a punishable offense.
Argument: Rathinam argued that the right to life under Article 21 includes the right to end one’s life, and that Section 309 IPC is unconstitutional.
Rules: Article 21 of the Constitution of India, guaranteeing the right to life and personal liberty.
Precedent: Earlier rulings on personal autonomy and whether the state could intervene in matters of an individual's choice regarding life.
Ratio of the Decision: The right to life does not inherently grant the right to die or to attempt suicide. Section 309 IPC remains valid, subject to further review.
Ruling: The Supreme Court initially ruled to decriminalize attempted suicide but later upheld the validity.

Case Name: State of Karnataka Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the financial allocations made by the central government under federal distribution policies are constitutionally valid.
Facts of the Case: Karnataka challenged the central government's allocation of funds, alleging that the state's financial rights were being unfairly curtailed.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of the central government, upholding the allocation of funds and dismissing Karnataka’s petition.
Argument: Karnataka argued that the financial allocation made by the central government was inequitable and unfairly limited the state's financial autonomy.
Rules: Fiscal federalism and financial distribution under constitutional provisions.
Precedent: Prior rulings on the distribution of financial resources between the state and central government.
Ratio of the Decision: Financial distribution between the central and state governments must be equitable.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the financial distribution policy of the central government but suggested improvements for a more equitable allocation.

Case Name: Rajbala Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether imposing minimum educational qualifications for contesting local body elections under the Haryana Panchayati Raj Act is constitutional.
Facts of the Case: Haryana amended its Panchayati Raj Act, making educational qualifications mandatory for contesting local body elections.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of the amendment, upholding the imposition of minimum educational qualifications for local body elections.
Argument: Rajbala argued that the amendment violated the fundamental right to equality under Article 14 by restricting access to electoral participation based on educational qualifications.
Rules: Electoral rights and reasonable restrictions under the Constitution, particularly Article 14.
Precedent: Previous decisions on the constitutionality of restrictions on electoral rights, especially those based on educational qualifications.
Ratio of the Decision: The imposition of educational qualifications for contesting elections does not violate the right to equality if it serves a rational purpose.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the Haryana law, determining that the educational qualifications were a reasonable classification.

Case Name: Municipal Board, Manglaur Vs. Sri Mahadeoji Maharaj
Issue Presented: Whether the land adjacent to the public road was part of municipal property or private property.
Facts of the Case: The Municipality intended to use the vacant land adjacent to the road for construction purposes, but the land's ownership was in dispute.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Court granted a permanent injunction in favor of the respondent, declaring the land was private property and not under municipal control.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the land was public property, falling under the jurisdiction of the Municipality. The respondent argued it was private land.
Statute: Municipal laws governing the use of land adjacent to public roads.
Rules: Interpretation of property rights regarding municipal authority over adjacent land.
Precedent: Previous cases related to land ownership and jurisdiction of municipalities over adjacent properties.
Ratio of the Decision: The case centered around determining if the land was private property or if it vested with the Municipality under public road laws.
Ruling: The matter was taken to the Supreme Court for further ruling.

Case Name: Union of India Vs. Association for Democratic Reforms
Issue Presented: Whether voters have the right to know a candidate’s criminal background, assets, and liabilities before elections.
Facts of the Case: The petition sought to make it compulsory for candidates to disclose their criminal records, assets, and liabilities to ensure transparency.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of disclosure, emphasizing the need for an informed electorate in democratic elections.
Argument: The petitioner contended that mandatory disclosure violated privacy rights and was not essential for electoral fairness.
Rules: Laws regarding electoral transparency and the disclosure of candidate information before elections.
Precedent: Prior judgments on electoral reforms and the extent of voter rights in relation to candidate information disclosure.
Ratio of the Decision: Voters have a right to know candidates' criminal records, assets, and liabilities to make an informed decision.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the need for transparency.

Case Name: Jindal Stainless Ltd. Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether state governments can impose an entry tax without violating the right to free trade between states.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that the imposition of entry tax by Haryana restricted interstate commerce.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the state’s authority to impose an entry tax as a valid exercise of power.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the entry tax amounted to an unconstitutional restriction on free trade between states.
Rules: Provisions under the Constitution relating to free trade, commerce, and taxation powers of states.
Precedent: Prior rulings on the constitutionality of state-imposed taxes and their impact on interstate commerce.
Ratio of the Decision: States have the power to impose taxes, such as entry taxes, as long as they do not infringe on the freedom of trade between states.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the imposition of entry tax, affirming that states can impose taxes that regulate trade within their jurisdiction.

Case Name: M/S Japan Airlines Co. Ltd Vs. Commissioner of Income Tax, New Delhi
Respondent: Commissioner of Income Tax, New Delhi
Issue Presented: Whether the payments made by Japan Airlines for landing and parking fees should be treated as rent for the purpose of TDS.
Facts of the Case: Japan Airlines paid airport charges for landing, parking, and maintenance of airport services and infrastructure.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Income Tax Department ruled that landing and parking charges are rent, thus subject to TDS.
Argument: The petitioner contested the classification of payments as rent under tax laws, arguing that such charges do not qualify as rent.
Statute: Section 194-I of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
Rules: Section 194-I, which applies to payments made for the use of land or property, is relevant for determining TDS applicability.
Precedent: Previous rulings on whether payments for services at airports, including landing and parking.
Ratio of the Decision: Payments for the use of airport land and services, such as parking and landing, qualify as rent.
Ruling: Awaiting Supreme Court’s decision on the tax treatment of landing and parking charges as rent for TDS purposes.

Case Name: State of Punjab Vs. Jagjit Singh
Issue Presented: Whether temporary employees are entitled to equal pay for performing duties identical to those of permanent employees.
Facts of the Case: Jagjit Singh, a temporary employee, claimed entitlement to equal pay for equal work as that of a permanent employee.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court ruled in favor of Jagjit Singh, affirming the principle of equal pay for equal work for temporary employees.
Argument: Respondent argued that temporary employees performing identical duties should receive the same pay as permanent employees.
Rules: The principle of equal pay for equal work applies to employees, whether permanent or temporary, if their work duties are the same.
Precedent: Earlier rulings emphasizing equal pay for equal work, particularly in cases involving temporary and permanent workers.
Ratio of the Decision: Temporary employees performing identical duties to permanent employees are entitled to the same pay and benefits.
Ruling: Supreme Court upheld the High Court’s decision, affirming the entitlement of temporary employees to equal pay for equal work.

Case Name: Kailas & Others Vs. State of Maharashtra
Issue Presented: Whether honor killings should be treated as separate offenses under criminal law and how they should be punished.
Facts of the Case: Kailas and others were convicted for killing a couple who married against their family’s and community’s norms.
Ruling by Lower Court: High Court upheld the conviction of the accused under Section 302 (murder) of the Indian Penal Code.
Argument: Petitioners argued for consideration of cultural and societal customs during sentencing, suggesting a less severe penalty.
Rules: The criminal law on murder applies to honor killings.
Precedent: Earlier rulings affirm that honor killings are to be treated as murder under the law and should attract strong penalties to deter such offenses.
Ratio of the Decision: The legal system does not allow honor killings to be treated as a lesser offense and mandates strict punishment to prevent such crimes.
Ruling: Supreme Court confirmed the sentence of life imprisonment for the accused, sending a strong message against honor killings.

Case Name: Krishna Pillai Vs. State of Madras
Issue Presented: Whether a confession of guilt in the illegal smuggling of gold is sufficient for conviction under the Land Customs Act.
Facts of the Case: Krishna Pillai was caught smuggling gold into India from Pondicherry without customs clearance.
Ruling by Lower Court: Trial Court convicted Krishna Pillai based on evidence of smuggling.
Argument: The defense argued that the confession may have been coerced or improperly obtained.
Statute: Section 7(1)(b) of the Land Customs Act, 1924 – dealing with unauthorized importation of goods.
Rules: Smuggling is prohibited under the Land Customs Act.
Precedent: Prior case law confirms that smuggling of goods across borders without clearance is punishable under customs law.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court considered whether confessions in smuggling cases could be sufficient.
Ruling: High Court upheld the conviction based on the smuggling charge but reversed the confiscation of gold.

Case Name: State of Rajasthan Vs. Jagannath
Issue Presented: Whether unauthorized occupation of government land can lead to eviction.
Facts of the Case: Jagannath was accused of encroaching on government land, and the case revolves around whether eviction laws should be enforced with rehabilitation for the encroachers.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the state's action for eviction, arguing that encroachment on government land cannot be allowed.
Argument: The respondent argued against eviction, suggesting that rehabilitation should be considered before eviction.
Rules: The law emphasizes protection of government land.
Precedent: Prior rulings confirm the state’s right to evict encroachers but emphasize the importance of fair rehabilitation for displaced persons.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court held that while eviction is justified for encroaching on government land.
Ruling: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court’s decision for eviction .

Case Name: National Legal Services Authority Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether transgender individuals should be legally recognized as a third gender.
Facts of the Case: The petition sought legal recognition for transgender individuals as a third gender.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled in favor of transgender rights, but it did not specify detailed policies for implementation of inclusive measures.
Argument: The petitioner argued that denying legal recognition as a third gender violated transgender individuals' dignity and equal protection under the law.
Statute: Constitutional provisions for equality, non-discrimination, and the right to life and personal liberty.
Rules: Transgender rights, dignity, and non-discrimination in legal recognition and public policies.
Precedent: Earlier cases related to fundamental rights and dignity for marginalized groups.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court recognized transgender individuals as the third gender, affirming their rights to equality.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of transgender recognition as the third gender.

Case Name: Mithu Vs. State of Punjab
Issue Presented: Whether the mandatory death penalty under Section 303 IPC, applied to offenders serving life sentences, is constitutional.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, an offender serving life imprisonment, challenged the mandatory death sentence imposed by Section 303 IPC for certain offenses.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the constitutionality.
Argument: The petitioner argued that mandatory death penalties violate the right to life and remove judicial discretion in sentencing.
Rules: The right to life and personal liberty as guaranteed by Article 21 of the Constitution.
Precedent: Earlier cases on the validity of mandatory sentences and judicial discretion.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled that mandatory death sentences violate constitutional rights by eliminating judicial discretion in sentencing.
Ruling: The Supreme Court declared Section 303 IPC unconstitutional, striking down the mandatory death penalty provision.

Case Name: D.K. Basu Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether guidelines should be issued for the protection of individuals from custodial torture and deaths.
Facts of the Case: A PIL was filed, pointing out instances of custodial torture and deaths.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court suggested procedural reforms to address custodial violence.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the absence of proper safeguards allowed for unchecked police brutality.
Rules: Regulations surrounding police accountability and custodial safety.
Precedent: Previous rulings related to human rights abuses by the police and the need for regulations to prevent abuse in custody.
Ratio of the Decision: Fundamental rights under Article 21 extend to detainees, and preventing custodial torture.
Ruling: The Supreme Court issued detailed guidelines to protect individuals from custodial torture and deaths.

Case Name: Ajay Hasia Vs. Khalid Mujib Sehravardi
Issue Presented: Whether government-funded institutions are considered 'State' for the purposes of enforcing fundamental rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged discriminatory admission practices at a technical institute, arguing it was a government-funded institution covered.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the technical institute was not a 'State'.
Argument: The petitioner argued that institutions receiving significant government funding should be classified as 'State'.
Rules: The interpretation of 'State' for the purpose of enforcing fundamental rights under the Constitution.
Precedent: Previous rulings on public institutions and their obligation to uphold fundamental rights.
Ratio of the Decision: Government-funded and controlled institutions are considered 'State' under Article 12 and must adhere to fundamental rights protections.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the technical institute was a 'State' under Article 12.

Case Name: Narmada Bachao Andolan Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the construction of the Sardar Sarovar Dam violates environmental protection laws.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner raised concerns about the environmental degradation and large-scale displacement caused by the construction of the Sardar Sarovar Dam.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the construction of the dam.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the dam's construction violated environmental laws and the rights of displaced people.
Rules: Resettlement and Rehabilitation Policies and Guidelines for displaced persons due to large development projects.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the environmental impact of development projects, resettlement.
Ratio of the Decision: Development projects like the dam must take into account both ecological sustainability and the rehabilitation of displaced individuals.
Ruling: The Supreme Court allowed the construction of the Sardar Sarovar Dam but mandated strict rehabilitation measures.

Case Name: The Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay Vs. S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co., Ltd.
Respondent: S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co., Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether remittances made under the agreement by S.K.F. as an agent for foreign corporations constitute taxable income under the Indian Income Tax Act.
Facts of the Case: S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co. Ltd. acted as an agent for foreign corporations.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that S. K. F. Ball Bearing Co. was merely acting as an agent.
Argument: The petitioner argued that S. K. F. was disguising profits as remittances to avoid tax, while the respondent contended that remittances were part of the funds transfer to the principal.
Statute: Section 4(1)(a) of the Indian Income-Tax Act.
Rules: The timing and characterization of the remittances are critical in determining whether they are taxable.
Precedent: Previous rulings on the taxability of funds remitted by agents, particularly in relation to the treatment of remittances made under contract.
Ratio of the Decision: The sale proceeds belong to the principal, and remittances made by the agent under contractual obligations.
Ruling: The Supreme Court overturned the High Court's ruling, clarifying that remittances made by S. K. F. as an agent were not taxable as profits.

Case Name: Turner Morrison And Co., Ltd Vs. Hungerford Investment Trust Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether Turner Morrison’s claim for reimbursement of super tax payments and interest was legally justified.
Facts of the Case: Turner Morrison sued Hungerford for reimbursement of super tax payments, asserting a lien on shares. Hungerford contended no obligation existed for reimbursement.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court ruled that Turner Morrison did not prove sufficient tax payments and barred the claim due to waiver and limitation.
Argument: The petitioner argued it was entitled to reimbursement for super tax payments and interest.
Statute: Contract law, taxation principles, and doctrines of waiver, estoppel, and limitation.
Rules: The court considered whether voluntary payments without legal obligation can be reimbursed.
Precedent: Previous rulings regarding estoppel, waiver, and limitation related to financial claims and contractual obligations.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, ruling that the claim for reimbursement was barred by waiver and limitation.
Ruling: Dismissed the appeal, stating that no valid claim.

Case Name: M/S. Corporate Ispat Alloys Limited Vs. M/S. Jayaswal Neco Industries Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the Company Court can proceed with the winding-up petition or must await the outcome of arbitration proceedings.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that the initiation of arbitration proceedings should not prevent the Company Court from proceeding with the winding-up petition.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Company Court deferred its decision, reasoning that the arbitration process was ongoing.
Argument: The petitioner contended that arbitration should not override the judicial process for winding-up proceedings.
Rules: The court should independently assess the insolvency situation without waiting for arbitration outcomes.
Precedent: Previous judicial precedents clarifying that arbitration cannot override or delay winding-up proceedings under insolvency laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The key issue is whether the winding-up petition should be delayed until arbitration proceedings are concluded.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that arbitration proceedings alone do not justify postponing a winding-up petition.

Case Name: National Organic Chemical Inds. Ltd Vs. Miheer H. Mafatlal
Issue Presented: Whether the Company Court exceeded its jurisdiction by deciding issues related to individual share ownership.
Facts of the Case: The Company Court decided on share allotment validity.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Company Court invalidated the share allotment under the influence of an injunction issued by the City Civil Court.
Argument: The appellant argued that the Company Court should refrain from deciding on individual shareholder titles.
Rules: Court's role in handling corporate disputes under Sections 391-394, avoiding jurisdiction overlap.
Precedent: Prior rulings have emphasized that a City Civil Court's injunction does not restrict the decision-making.
Ratio of the Decision: The court ruled that shareholder ownership issues must be resolved through statutory rectification procedures.
Ruling: The Supreme Court clarified that disputes concerning share ownership should be handled through the statutory rectification process.

Case Name: Anjuman Islamia and Others Vs. Munshi Tegh Ali and Others
Issue Presented: Whether Badi Takia was privately owned or had been dedicated to religious use as a wakf property.
Facts of the Case: The dispute arose over the ownership of Badi Takia, with plaintiffs asserting it was their private property and defendants claiming it was a wakf.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Trial Court upheld the plaintiffs' claim of ownership and ruled the property was not a wakf.
Argument: The plaintiffs argued that there was no formal dedication to make the property a wakf.
Statute: Legal principles of property ownership and the formalities required for creating a wakf.
Rules: Mere religious use does not automatically imply wakf status unless supported by clear evidence of dedication.
Precedent: Previous cases have set the precedent that religious use alone is not enough to establish wakf.
Ratio of the Decision: Management by religious figures does not imply the property is automatically a wakf without formal dedication or evidence.
Ruling: The Court affirmed the plaintiffs' ownership of the property.

Case Name: Hindustan Petroleum Corpn. Ltd Vs. Ashok Ranghba Ambre
Issue Presented: Whether the respondent's temporary employment should be converted into permanent status after long service.
Facts of the Case: The respondent worked as an ad hoc employee, seeking permanent status after long service.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Labour Court held that the respondent had worked sufficiently to gain permanent status.
Argument: HPCL argued that the respondent’s employment was not regular, and the Labour Court misinterpreted the employment nature.
Statute: Labour laws under Indian statutes governing employment and workers' rights.
Rules: Casual or ad hoc employment cannot be treated as permanent without formal recruitment procedures.
Precedent: Precedent establishes that casual or temporary employees cannot be made permanent without formal recruitment.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court clarified that informal employment cannot be converted to permanent status without formal recruitment procedures being followed.
Ruling: The Court ruled in favor of HPCL, emphasizing that permanent employment requires formal recruitment procedures.

Case Name: Krishnakumar Mills Company Limited and Another Vs. State of Gujarat and Others
Petitioner: Krishnakumar Mills Company Limited and Another
Issue Presented: Whether the appellant’s land, vital for their textile mills, should have been excluded from compulsory acquisition.
Facts of the Case: The appellant's land was situated within a larger block of land acquired for industrial development by the government.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the appellant's land was necessary for the larger industrial development and could not be excluded from acquisition.
Argument: The appellant argued that the land was crucial to their business and should not be acquired.
Statute: Gujarat Industrial Development Act, 1962 and applicable constitutional principles governing land acquisition for public purpose.
Rules: Once land is deemed necessary for public use under law, it cannot be selectively exempted from acquisition.
Precedent: Legal precedents uphold the government's authority to acquire land for public purposes.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court determined that the appellant’s land was essential for the broader industrial development.
Ruling: The Supreme Court rejected the appellant’s plea.

Case Name: Pratima Chowdhury Vs. Kalpana Mukherjee
Issue Presented: Whether the ownership transfer process executed by the Society and the Deputy Registrar was in accordance with the legal requirements.
Facts of the Case: Pratima Chowdhury's ownership transfer was approved by the housing society.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Court ruled in favor of Pratima Chowdhury, affirming her legal ownership following a compliant transfer process.
Argument: The process of ownership transfer was lawful, meeting all necessary legal conditions.
Statute: Co-operative Societies Act and housing society rules governing ownership transfers and formal approvals.
Rules: Co-operative housing transfers must comply with formal rules, including approval from the society and the Deputy Registrar.
Precedent: Precedents affirm that approved transfers within a cooperative housing society.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court confirmed that ownership transfers, once approved by the society and Registrar.
Ruling: The property rights were transferred legally, securing Pratima Chowdhury’s rightful ownership of the property.

Case Name: P.P. Enterprises Etc. Vs. Union of India and Others Etc.
Issue Presented: Whether the classification imposed by the government on sugar storage limits was reasonable.
Facts of the Case: The government implemented different storage limits for sugar, claiming that regional needs warranted such differentiation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court determined that the government's order was regulatory in nature and not unconstitutional.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the classification and storage limits unfairly impacted dealers in regions outside of Calcutta.
Statute: Directive Principles of State Policy and economic regulations under the Constitution.
Rules: Economic restrictions imposed by the state must be reasonable and have a legitimate public interest aim.
Precedent: Precedents affirm that economic regulations by the government are valid if they are rational.
Ratio of the Decision: The court upheld the government’s regulations on sugar storage, validating them as a reasonable economic measure in the public interest.
Ruling: The regulation was deemed constitutional and aligned with economic policy, as it had a valid public interest basis.

Case Name: Ashok Kumar Barik Vs. State of Orissa
Issue Presented: Whether the prosecution proved the guilt of the petitioner beyond a reasonable doubt under Section 302 of the IPC.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, in a relationship with the deceased, acted under societal pressures leading to frustration.
Ruling by Lower Court: The conviction was made under Section 302 IPC, based on key witness testimonies and medical evidence.
Argument: The petitioner argued that there were doubts in the prosecution's case and that the absence of a prior criminal record should be considered.
Rules: Guilt in criminal cases must be established beyond a reasonable doubt, according to the Indian Evidence Act and IPC.
Precedent: Precedent cases emphasize that circumstantial evidence must lead to a single.
Ratio of the Decision: The court found that the prosecution’s evidence was unreliable and did not establish guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
Ruling: The court acquitted the petitioner, citing unreliable witness testimonies and insufficient evidence to convict beyond a reasonable doubt.

Case Name: Kartar Singh Vs. The Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether the order by the Central Board of Revenue was legally justified and adhered to due process.
Facts of the Case: Kartar Singh was accused of being linked to smuggled gold shipments based on the findings of the Central Board of Revenue.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Board's conclusion was based on weak and circumstantial evidence linking Kartar Singh to smuggling activities.
Argument: The petitioner argued that there was no direct evidence linking him to smuggling and that procedural violations rendered the order invalid.
Rules: Due process must be followed in administrative decisions, and assumptions cannot be the basis for a conviction.
Precedent: Previous rulings highlight the necessity of procedural fairness and substantive evidence in administrative decisions.
Ratio of the Decision: The Board's overreach in its jurisdiction and failure to adhere to due process rendered the order invalid.
Ruling: The court overturned the Board’s decision, acquitting the petitioner due to lack of concrete evidence and procedural lapses.

Case Name: Surya Kant Roy Vs. Imamul Hai Khan
Issue Presented: Whether the respondent was disqualified due to holding an office of profit and if election malpractice was proven.
Facts of the Case: Allegations were made that the respondent held an office of profit and that government influence led to election misconduct.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court dismissed the petition due to lack of substantial evidence supporting the claims of electoral malpractice.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the respondent’s position was influenced by government funding, making it an office of profit.
Statute: Election laws related to candidate disqualification and the concept of holding an office of profit.
Rules: Allegations in election petitions must be backed by substantial evidence proving direct impact on election outcomes.
Precedent: Previous rulings have required clear evidence of electoral malpractice affecting the election results.
Ratio of the Decision: The court found no significant financial or administrative advantage.
Ruling: The petition was rejected, affirming the election results due to lack of substantial proof.

Case Name: Punjab Traders And Ors Vs. State Of Punjab And Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the Amendment Act, 1973, violated fundamental rights by imposing unfair regulations.
Facts of the Case: The petitioners claimed that the amendment imposed unfair regulations, but no substantial proof was presented.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court found no valid basis for the claims and ruled against the petitioners.
Argument: The amendment did not specifically target the petitioners or violate any fundamental rights.
Statute: Constitutional laws related to taxation, trade, and fundamental rights.
Rules: Article 14 protects equality, but discrimination must be proven for it to apply.
Precedent: Past rulings clarifying when an amendment significantly alters constitutional rights.
Ratio of the Decision: No substantial proof was provided to show that the amendment unfairly discriminated.
Ruling: The court upheld the amendment, ruling against the petitioners.

Case Name: Reena Suresh Alhat Vs. State Of Maharashtra And Anr
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition violated electoral rights.
Facts of the Case: The Bombay High Court rejected the petition, citing an alternative remedy for election disputes.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court dismissed the petition, stating that election disputes must be addressed through proper channels.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the High Court should have considered the substantive electoral issues.
Statute: Indian constitutional provisions on electoral fairness and legal remedies.
Rules: Courts typically avoid intervening in election disputes unless fundamental rights are affected.
Precedent: Article 329 of the Constitution restricts judicial intervention in election matters.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court found that the case raised substantial questions about electoral rights.
Ruling: The Supreme Court agreed to hear the case, highlighting the importance of electoral fairness.

Case Name: Karimbil Kunhikoman Vs. State Of Kerala
Issue Presented: Whether differential compensation for land acquisition violates fairness.
Facts of the Case: The government applied a tiered formula to reduce compensation based on land value.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court upheld the tiered compensation approach.
Argument: The petitioner argued that compensation should be uniform and not value-based.
Statute: Constitutional provisions on land acquisition and compensation fairness.
Rules: Fair compensation requires equal treatment of landowners.
Precedent: Landmark cases on eminent domain and just compensation.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled against discriminatory compensation deductions.
Ruling: The Court held that landowners must receive equal compensation for similar acquisitions.

Case Name: Moideenkutty Haji Vs. Director General & Others
Issue Presented: Whether an additional aluminum roof violated heritage conservation laws.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner added a roof modification to a building in a heritage zone.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court ruled that the modification violated conservation laws.
Argument: The petitioner argued the modification was minor and meant for protection.
Statute: Legal framework governing heritage sites and structural modifications.
Rules: Prior approval is mandatory for any modification in heritage areas.
Precedent: Cases affirming strict compliance with heritage protection laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The court ruled that intent does not override legal compliance.
Ruling: The structure was ordered to be removed for non-compliance.

Case Name: S. S. Shetty Vs. Bharat Nidhi, Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether reinstatement compensation should include pension and gratuity.
Facts of the Case: The employment bye-laws approved by RBI included pension and gratuity.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal upheld the employee’s claim, ensuring pension rights.
Argument: Pension and gratuity should not impact the computation of compensation.
Statute: Statutory provisions governing pension and gratuity.
Rules: Pension rights must be factored into employment compensation decisions.
Precedent: Past rulings affirming pension as a statutory employment benefit.
Ratio of the Decision: Employment benefits must be determined per labor laws and precedents.
Ruling: The employee was reinstated with compensation, including pension rights.

Case Name: Essco Fabs Pvt. Ltd. Vs. State of Haryana
Issue Presented: Whether private industrial expansion qualifies as 'public purpose'.
Facts of the Case: Essco argued its industrial growth and exports justified land acquisition.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled against Essco, stating expansion was not a necessity.
Argument: Essco argued that industrial growth aligns with economic development.
Rules: Private industry expansion is not classified as a public purpose.
Precedent: Previous rulings rejecting private firms' land acquisition requests.
Ratio of the Decision: Courts determine public necessity based on statutory definitions.
Ruling: The appeal was rejected as private expansion lacked public necessity.

Case Name: Pankaj Kumar Vs. State of Jharkhand & Ors.
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner was entitled to reservation benefits after state reorganization.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was employed in Bihar but was absorbed into Jharkhand’s services post-reorganization, losing previous reservation benefits.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that reservation benefits were state-specific.
Argument: The state argued that benefits should be determined by the domicile policy of Jharkhand.
Rules: Service conditions must remain unchanged post-reorganization.
Precedent: Cases protecting transferred employees’ rights under similar reorganization laws.
Ratio of the Decision: The case examined whether service conditions could be altered post-reorganization.
Ruling: The appeal was upheld, and the petitioner’s reservation rights were restored.

Case Name: K. Gopinathan Nair and Others Vs. State of Kerala
Issue Presented: Whether cashewnut purchases via CCI were part of the import process.
Facts of the Case: Petitioners claimed their purchases through CCI were import transactions.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Kerala High Court ruled that these were post-import sales taxable under domestic law.
Argument: Petitioners argued their purchases were direct import transactions.
Statute: Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963; Central Sales Tax Act, 1956 (Section 5(2)).
Rules: Goods must move in direct connection to an international trade contract to be tax-exempt.
Precedent: Cases differentiating import transactions from local resale transactions.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized that post-import resale does not qualify for tax exemption.
Ruling: The court upheld sales tax on cashewnut purchases.

Case Name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd Vs. State of Bihar
Issue Presented: Whether further payments of market fees are due from Harinagar Sugar Mills.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner paid part of the market fee before appealing and contested further payments.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled payments could not be refunded and no further payments were required.
Argument: The petitioner argued for refund based on prior legal rulings and contested further payment recovery.
Statute: Bihar Market Fee Act (Section 27-B); Articles 226 and 142 of the Constitution.
Rules: Precedent from Belsund Sugar Mills case, where past payments are not refundable.
Precedent: Belsund Sugar Mills case, addressing the non-refundability of market fees.
Ratio of the Decision: Past payments are valid, but no further payments or recoveries are justified.
Ruling: The appeals were dismissed in favor of the State of Bihar.

Case Name: P.C. Sethi Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether temporary assistants are entitled to seniority under the 1971 Office Memorandum.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner claimed eligibility for seniority based on the 1971 Office Memorandum.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the seniority rules based on prior memoranda.
Argument: The petitioner argued for eligibility under the 1971 memorandum without extra conditions.
Statute: Articles 14, 16, and 309 of the Constitution of India; Office Memoranda of 1949 and 1971.
Rules: Seniority must follow structured absorption, as determined by the government rules.
Precedent: Prior rulings affirmed that seniority rules for government employees follow structured guidelines.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court ruled that seniority was not automatically granted and upheld the structured absorption process.
Ruling: The court upheld the government's seniority rules, dismissing the petition.

Case Name: Ruchi Majoo Vs. Sanjeev Majoo
Issue Presented: Whether the father is entitled to visitation and overnight custody during vacations.
Facts of the Case: The father sought visitation rights and overnight custody during vacations, claiming unfair restrictions on his relationship with the child.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court allowed limited visitation, but did not define overnight custody.
Argument: The appellant argued that the father’s absence and the child’s reluctance to communicate should limit visitation.
Statute: Guardian and Wards Act, Principles of Child Custody under Family Law.
Rules: Non-custodial parents are entitled to reasonable visitation rights.
Precedent: Judicial precedents emphasize the importance of fair visitation for non-custodial parents.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision reinforced the principle that non-custodial parents are entitled to visitation.
Ruling: The court granted the father visitation rights, ensuring fair access to the child.

Case Name: Charanjit Pal Jindal Vs. M/s. L.N. Metalics
Issue Presented: Whether the appellant’s conviction for dishonored cheques should stand.
Facts of the Case: The appellant failed to clear outstanding dues and issued dishonored cheques.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Trial Court convicted the appellant for dishonoring cheques.
Argument: The respondent argued that dishonored cheques indicated intentional non-payment under the Negotiable Instruments Act.
Statute: Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act, 1881.
Rules: Dishonored cheques due to insufficient funds lead to legal consequences.
Precedent: Precedent confirms liability for dishonored cheques under Section 138.
Ratio of the Decision: Issuing a cheque with insufficient funds constitutes a criminal offense under Section 138.
Ruling: The High Court upheld the conviction for issuing dishonored cheques.

Case Name: State of Haryana Vs. Northern Indian Glass Industries Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether the land resumption followed legal procedures and natural justice.
Facts of the Case: The dispute concerned the land acquisition and compensation, with prolonged litigation over fair compensation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Collector upheld the compensation but the case was contested.
Argument: The State argued that land resumption was valid due to industrial non-compliance.
Rules: The land resumption must follow legal procedures and respect natural justice.
Precedent: The court upheld the principle that land resumption requires due process and natural justice.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized procedural fairness and compliance in land resumption.
Ruling: The High Court's decision was upheld, reaffirming the requirement of procedural fairness.

Case Name: Ms. Sarita Singh Vs. M/s Shree Infosoft Private Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner was legally on deputation and the legal implications of such an arrangement.
Facts of the Case: The dispute involved whether the petitioner was sent on deputation, and if so, whether this was legally valid.
Ruling by Lower Court: Not specified
Argument: The petitioner argued that deputation requires formal agreement and documentation, which were lacking here.
Rules: The court considered the legal requirement for formal consent and documentation for deputation.
Precedent: Precedents on deputation, such as State of Punjab v. Inder Singh, established the requirement for explicit documentation.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling reinforced the requirement for formal documentation and agreement to establish deputation.
Ruling: The court ruled in favor of the petitioner, confirming that she was not legally on deputation.

Case Name: Parmanand Patel (D) Th. Lrs. Vs. Sudha A. Chowgule
Petitioner: Legal representatives of late Parmanand Patel
Issue Presented: Whether the execution of property division documents was valid or influenced by coercion.
Facts of the Case: The dispute involves whether the division of property was conducted fairly or under undue influence.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court upheld the validity of the documents in favor of Sudha.
Argument: The petitioners claimed coercion and undue influence undermined the validity of the documents, warranting reconsideration.
Statute: Indian Contract Act, Evidence Act, Succession Laws.
Rules: The court reviewed the fairness of the execution process and Sudha's legal authority in the matter.
Precedent: The case relied on previous rulings concerning the validity of property agreements executed under duress.
Ratio of the Decision: Despite acknowledging procedural irregularities, the court upheld the property settlement as legally valid.
Ruling: The High Court affirmed Sudha’s entitlement to the property, though it acknowledged procedural concerns.

Case Name: Patel Ahmed Mohammad Vs. Balwant Singh Rajput
Issue Presented: Whether the election of Patel Ahmed Mohammad was affected by corrupt practices and procedural errors.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the election alleging bribery, electoral malpractice, and vote miscounting.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the election petition was validly filed within the time limit and dismissed the preliminary objections.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the election was influenced by corrupt practices and that the vote counting procedure was flawed.
Statute: Representation of the People Act, 1951; Indian Election Laws.
Rules: The court considered whether procedural issues could outweigh substantial claims of corrupt practices in an election petition.
Precedent: Emphasizes that electoral challenges must be addressed on their merits, not dismissed on procedural errors alone.
Ratio of the Decision: The case highlighted that substantial allegations of corruption must be considered, even if procedural errors exist.
Ruling: The High Court allowed the case to proceed to trial, dismissing the appellant's objections to the petition.

Case Name: Podar Mills Limited Vs. State Bank of India
Issue Presented: Whether the court’s discretion in appointing a receiver was appropriate given the circumstances of the loan default.
Facts of the Case: The dispute arose from Podar Mills' default on a loan to the State Bank of India, resulting in a request for a receiver to be appointed to manage the company’s assets.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court appointed a receiver to protect creditor rights after considering the company's loan default.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the Custodian was already managing the assets, so the receiver's appointment was unnecessary and harmful.
Statute: Transfer of Property Act, 1882; Indian Contract Act.
Rules: The ruling considered creditor protection laws and judicial powers in cases of financial disputes.
Precedent: Judicial intervention is necessary in cases where creditor interests are jeopardized by financial mismanagement.
Ratio of the Decision: Emphasizes that court discretion in appointing receivers is justified when it serves the protection of creditor interests.
Ruling: The court upheld the appointment of the receiver, ruling in favor of the State Bank of India.

Case Name: The Godavari Sugar Mills Ltd Vs. Shri D. K. Worlikar
Issue Presented: Whether the interpretation of the notification’s scope by the Labour Appellate Tribunal was correct under the Industrial Disputes Act.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner argued that the notification applied only to sugar manufacturing and its by-products, not to the broader industry.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Labour Court ruled in favor of the petitioner, limiting the scope of the notification to sugar manufacturing and by-products.
Argument: The respondent argued that the notification should apply to a broader scope than just sugar manufacturing.
Rules: Focused on the appropriate interpretative authority of the Tribunal in determining the scope of the notification.
Precedent: Stresses the importance of precise interpretation of statutory notifications.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision emphasized the need for precise interpretation of legal notifications, restricting their scope unless explicitly broader.
Ruling: The court ruled that the Tribunal’s broad interpretation was incorrect, confirming that the notification was limited in scope.

Case Name: RANI Vs. NATIONAL INSURANCE COMPANY LTD
Petitioner: Rani (Claimants in Civil Appeal No.9078 of 2017) and Anand
Respondent: National Insurance Company Ltd & Offending vehicle owner
Issue Presented: Whether the claimants are entitled to enhanced compensation, and whether the Insurance Company should pay first and recover from the vehicle owner.
Facts of the Case: The claimants filed appeals seeking enhanced compensation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal provided compensation but did not consider the issue of liability for further compensation by the Insurance Company.
Argument: The claimants argued that the Insurance Company should compensate them upfront and recover the amount from the vehicle owner at a later stage.
Statute: Motor Vehicles Act, CPC Order 41 Rule 33.
Rules: Focused on whether statutory provisions require the Insurance Company to compensate the claimants first and recover from the vehicle owner later.
Precedent: The case reaffirmed that an insurer’s liability can be limited due to statutory compliance issues.
Ratio of the Decision: The court examined statutory limitations affecting insurance claims and concluded that the insurer's liability is based on statutory compliance, with "pay and recover" considered based on specific circumstances.
Ruling: The court upheld the principle that insurance liability is contingent on statutory compliance, and the "pay and recover" issue was addressed in light of the case's circumstances.

Case Name: B. M. Ramaswamy Vs. B. M. Krishnamurthy And Others
Issue Presented: Whether non-compliance with electoral registration procedures affected the petitioner's eligibility to contest elections.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was denied inclusion in the electoral roll due to procedural errors, which led to the dispute over his ability to contest elections.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court denied the petitioner's request for inclusion in the electoral roll, citing procedural deficiencies in the electoral registration.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the electoral registration process should not be strictly adhered to if it unfairly deprived him of his right to contest.
Statute: Representation of the People Act, 1950; Election Commission Rules.
Rules: The Court interpreted the relevant provisions under the Representation of the People Act.
Precedent: The case reaffirmed the principle that strict adherence to election procedures ensures fairness.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court emphasized that compliance with electoral registration procedures is mandatory to ensure that the electoral process remains fair and legitimate.
Ruling: The court ruled that failure to comply with electoral registration procedures can invalidate a person's right to contest elections.

Case Name: Bhabhi Vs. Sheo Govind & Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the respondent’s request for sample inspection was legally valid, considering the lack of specific evidence and material particulars.
Facts of the Case: The respondent requested a sample inspection of ballot papers but did not offer specific or concrete evidence to support claims of election irregularities.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court allowed the petition for sample inspection, which lacked verified claims or procedural justification.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the absence of specific evidence and procedural lapses invalidated the respondent’s request for ballot inspection.
Statute: Conduct of Election Rules, 1961; Election Commission Regulations.
Rules: The Court highlighted that sample inspection in election disputes must be supported by concrete evidence.
Precedent: The Court reaffirmed that election disputes require concrete evidence.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court held that the burden of proof in election-related disputes lies with the petitioner.
Ruling: The Court held that the petition was not maintainable, emphasizing that the request for sample inspection could not proceed without clear.

Case Name: Kathiawar Industries Limited Vs. Jaffrabad Municipality
Issue Presented: Whether processed salt, before being exported, is subject to octroi duty.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner processed salt within octroi limits but argued it was only processed for export and should not be subject to local tax.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled that the processing of salt within the limits transformed the goods sufficiently to fall under octroi taxation laws.
Argument: The petitioner maintained that since the salt was processed for export, and not for local consumption.
Statute: Section 3 of the Octroi Act; Entry 52, List II of the Indian Constitution.
Rules: The Court held that the term "use" includes processing that alters the goods, making them subject to tax.
Precedent: The decision established that octroi laws apply even when goods are processed but not sold within municipal limits.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court emphasized that any modification or processing of goods within octroi limits, even for export.
Ruling: The Court ruled in favor of Jaffrabad Municipality, affirming that the processed salt was subject to octroi duty.

Case Name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras Vs. M/S. Madurai Mills Co. Limited
Issue Presented: Whether the distribution of assets upon voluntary liquidation triggers capital gains tax under the Income-tax Act.
Facts of the Case: Madurai Mills Co. Ltd. received assets upon the voluntary liquidation of three companies, and the revenue sought to impose capital gains tax.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal ruled that the distribution of assets upon voluntary liquidation was not subject to capital gains tax.
Argument: The petitioner claimed that the distribution of assets was subject to capital gains tax because of the difference between the received value and the initial investment.
Statute: Section 12B(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; Corporate liquidation tax laws.
Rules: Section 12B(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; Corporate liquidation tax laws.
Precedent: The decision reaffirmed that capital gains tax is applicable only when there is a transfer, which did not occur in this case.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court clarified that the tax liability for capital gains is triggered only when there is a sale, exchange.
Ruling: The Court ruled in favor of Madurai Mills Co. Ltd., overturning the capital gains tax assessment.

Case Name: Union of India and Anr Vs. Pfizer Limited and Ors
Issue Presented: Whether the government had the jurisdiction to impose a ban on pharmaceutical products without proper legislative authority.
Facts of the Case: The government imposed a ban on certain pharmaceutical products.
Ruling by Lower Court: The court ruled in favor of Pfizer and others, asserting that the ban was imposed without proper legal backing.
Argument: The petitioners argued that public health concerns justified the ban.
Statute: Section 26A of the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940.
Rules: The court interpreted that statutory authority must not exceed its defined boundaries under the relevant statute.
Precedent: The decision underscored the principle that governmental actions must align with legislative authority and safeguards.
Ratio of the Decision: The court ruled that the government had overstepped its jurisdiction by enforcing a ban without adequate legislative authority.
Ruling: The Court upheld the petitioners' claims, concluding that the government lacked the authority to impose the ban.

Case Name: Indian Young Lawyers Association Vs. State of Kerala (Sabarimala Case)
Issue Presented: Whether the restriction on the entry of women into the Sabarimala Temple infringes on gender equality and constitutional rights.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner challenged the restriction on women of menstruating age being denied entry into the Sabarimala Temple.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the restriction, affirming the religious customs of the temple.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the temple’s restrictions on women violated Articles 14, 15, and 25 of the Indian Constitution.
Rules: The case addressed the conflict between religious freedom and constitutional rights to equality and non-discrimination.
Precedent: The Court considered previous cases dealing with religious practices and their impact on constitutional rights, especially equality.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court ruled that religious practices cannot infringe upon fundamental constitutional rights, particularly gender equality.
Ruling: The Supreme Court struck down the restriction, affirming women’s right to enter the Sabarimala Temple in accordance with constitutional rights.

Case Name: State of Maharashtra Vs. Praful Desai
Issue Presented: Whether video conferencing is a valid method to record witness testimony under the law.
Facts of the Case: The prosecution sought to record witness testimony via video conferencing due to the witness's inability to travel.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that video conferencing was not a valid means of recording witness testimony.
Argument: The petitioner argued that the use of video conferencing should be allowed to expedite justice and overcome practical constraints.
Rules: The case involved balancing evidentiary law with the possibilities of technological advancements.
Precedent: The Court reviewed previous cases dealing with the use of technology in legal proceedings.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that video conferencing is permissible for recording witness testimony as long as necessary safeguards are in place.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of allowing video conferencing for witness testimony, with certain safeguards.

Case Name: Shabnam Vs. Union of India
Issue Presented: Whether delay in the rejection of a mercy petition on death row violates Article 21 of the Constitution.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, facing the death penalty, argued that delay in considering her mercy petition was inhumane and unconstitutional.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court upheld the death sentence, ruling that the delay did not violate constitutional rights.
Argument: The petitioner contended that the delay in considering her mercy petition violated her rights under Article 21 of the Constitution.
Rules: The case involved interpreting whether delays in mercy petitions could violate the constitutional right to life and dignity.
Precedent: The Court considered previous decisions on the impact of delays in mercy petitions on death row prisoners.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court held that inordinate delay in deciding a mercy petition can justify commuting the death sentence to life imprisonment.
Ruling: The Supreme Court commuted the death sentence to life imprisonment, ruling that the delay in considering the mercy petition violated Article 21.

Case Name: Ritesh Sinha Vs. State of Uttar Pradesh
Issue Presented: Whether compelling the petitioner to provide a voice sample violates the right against self-incrimination.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner, in a criminal investigation, refused to provide a voice sample, asserting that it violated his constitutional right against self-incrimination.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that providing a voice sample did not constitute self-incrimination.
Argument: The petitioner contended that compelling him to provide a voice sample would violate his fundamental right against self-incrimination.
Rules: The case involved the interpretation of whether voice samples can be considered testimonial.
Precedent: The Court considered earlier judgments on the scope of self-incrimination, specifically regarding the collection of bodily evidence.
Ratio of the Decision: The Supreme Court ruled that providing voice samples does not violate Article 20(3), as it constitutes physical evidence, not testimony.
Ruling: The Supreme Court confirmed that compelling the provision of a voice sample does not infringe upon the right against self-incrimination.

Case Name: Commissioner of Income Tax II Vs. M/s. Modipon Ltd
Issue Presented: Whether PLA deposits can be treated as tax payments.
Facts of the Case: The Revenue contested the accounting treatment of PLA deposits.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court had ruled in favor of the taxpayer, considering the deposits as excise duty payments.
Argument: The Revenue claimed that PLA deposits were only advance payments and not final tax obligations.
Statute: Section 3 of the Central Excise Act, 1944; Rule 173G of the Central Excise Rules, 1944.
Rules: The case clarified the status of PLA deposits and underscored the importance of consistent procedural application in tax assessments.
Precedent: The ruling stressed the importance of consistent interpretation and application of statutory provisions in administrative procedures.
Ratio of the Decision: The court ruled that statutory provisions must be applied practically and fairly to ensure consistency in tax treatment.
Ruling: The Court confirmed that PLA deposits should be treated as payments of excise duty.

Case Name: Gopal Singh And Others Vs. Ujagar Singh And Others
Issue Presented: Whether the daughter’s gift to her sons accelerated their estate.
Facts of the Case: The trial court ruled that the property was non-ancestral, and Mst. Biro’s gift to her sons was absolute, thereby barring the plaintiffs’ claim to reversionary rights.
Ruling by Lower Court: The plaintiffs' suit was dismissed as the trial judge found that the property was non-ancestral, and the daughter’s gift was valid.
Argument: The plaintiffs argued that the lower courts erred in holding that the property was non-ancestral and that the gift was absolute.
Statute: Customary law principles related to property inheritance and alienation by female heirs.
Rules: The decision was based on customary law, which determined that collaterals beyond the fifth degree had no claim over the property.
Precedent: The case established that ancestral property claims must be substantiated with evidence.
Ratio of the Decision: The court concluded that the gift by the daughter to her sons was valid and that the plaintiffs' claims were barred.
Ruling: The Privy Council dismissed the plaintiffs' appeal.

Case Name: State of Kerala Vs. N. Sami Iyer
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court correctly determined that the turnover was not subject to additional taxation under the new sales tax law.
Facts of the Case: The dispute focused on whether taxing a transaction already taxed under the previous regime was valid.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court upheld the initial tax assessment, indicating that the turnover had already been taxed.
Argument: The petitioner argued that since the turnover had been taxed under the Madras Act, imposing further tax was invalid.
Statute: Provisions governing the transition of tax laws, specifically the prohibition on double taxation under the Madras General Sales Tax Act.
Rules: Once tax is assessed at the purchase point, subsequent taxation on the same turnover is prohibited.
Precedent: Prior decisions emphasized that if a turnover has been taxed under the old regime, it should not attract additional tax under the new regime.
Ratio of the Decision: The court ruled that additional taxation on a turnover already taxed is invalid, as statutory provisions must be applied consistently with their practical intent.
Ruling: The judgment upheld the assessee’s objection, confirming that the turnover was not liable to further taxation under the new sales tax law.

Case Name: Punj Lloyd Limited Vs. Corporate Risks India Pvt. Ltd.
Issue Presented: Whether the dismissal of the complaint by the National Consumer Disputes Redressal Commission on the basis of complex contractual issues was correct.
Facts of the Case: The appellant contended that the broker misrepresented its ability to secure proper coverage, leading to the complaint.
Ruling by Lower Court: The complaint was rejected, as the forum held that consumer protection bodies are not suited to resolve complex contractual disputes.
Argument: Punj Lloyd argued that the Commission should have issued notice.
Rules: The decision examined the limits of consumer forums in handling contractual interpretation issues.
Precedent: Prior rulings emphasized the need to distinguish contractual disputes from genuine consumer grievances.
Ratio of the Decision: The court ruled that contractual issues require detailed scrutiny before dismissal, particularly when they affect consumer rights.
Ruling: The appeal was upheld, and the complaint was reinstated for further adjudication under consumer law.

Case Name: State of Assam Vs. The Amalgamated Tea Estates Company Limited & Others
Respondent: The Amalgamated Tea Estates Company Limited & Others
Issue Presented: Whether the notification that expanded municipal jurisdiction to include part of the Naharkatia Tea Estate for taxation was legally justified.
Facts of the Case: The notification by the Assam government brought part of the Naharkatia Tea Estate under municipal taxation.
Ruling by Lower Court: The High Court ruled that the notification was invalid and prevented municipal tax collection on the tea estate.
Argument: The petitioner (State) argued that the inclusion was a policy decision with legal consequences.
Rules: The case examined the limits of municipal governance and clarified that tax imposition must be linked to actual municipal benefits.
Precedent: Prior decisions have held that taxation without corresponding service provision is not justified.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court held that imposing tax on the estate without tangible municipal benefits is an abuse of power.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the tea estate owners.

Case Name: Union Public Service Commission Vs. Shristi Singh
Issue Presented: Whether the UPSC misinterpreted the required experience for the Drug Inspector post.
Facts of the Case: UPSC advertised that candidates must have 18 months’ experience in drug quality control for the Drug Inspector post.
Ruling by Lower Court: The Tribunal ruled that Singh should be given a fair opportunity to compete in the selection process.
Argument: UPSC argued that Singh’s rejection was justified because her experience certificates did not explicitly confirm the 18-month requirement.
Rules: The case examined whether the experience criteria should be applied strictly or flexibly.
Precedent: Prior cases emphasized the need for clearly defined experience criteria in employment advertisements.
Ratio of the Decision: The Court held that the experience requirement must be interpreted in light of both statutory provisions.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of Singh, finding that the UPSC’s rejection did not have a sound legal basis.

Case Name: Special Officer, Commerce, North Eastern Electricity Company of Orissa and Anr Vs. Raghunath Paper Mills Private Limited and Anr
Petitioner: Special Officer, Commerce, North Eastern Electricity Company of Orissa and Another
Respondent: Raghunath Paper Mills Private Limited and Another
Issue Presented: Whether outstanding electricity dues from the previous owner can be transferred to the new purchaser despite a fresh power supply agreement with NESCO.
Facts of the Case: The respondent acquired the factory unit through liquidation and signed a new agreement with NESCO, yet NESCO sought to recover arrears from the previous owner.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled in favor of NESCO’s demand, dismissing the petition because it held that arrears were a precondition for power supply.
Argument: The petitioner contended that outstanding arrears should not be imposed on the new purchaser under a fresh agreement, as such liability should not transfer without explicit notice.
Statute: Electricity Act, 2003; Companies Act, 1956; Orissa Electricity Laws.
Rules: The case examined if the regulatory framework permits power suppliers to recover previous arrears from a new buyer in the absence of prior notification.
Precedent: Prior rulings have held that transfer of outstanding dues requires a clear statutory basis.
Ratio of the Decision: The court clarified that the new power supply agreement should be treated separately.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the respondent.

Case Name: Subodh Gopal Bose Vs. Ajit Kumar Haldar And Others
Issue Presented: Whether the plaintiff could claim the estate free from encumbrances as per the amended Section 37 of the Bengal Tenancy Act.
Facts of the Case: The plaintiff purchased the estate, sold for arrears, and sought to annul tenures under the amended Section 37 of the Bengal Tenancy Act.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court ruled that the defendants could not prove their claim under Section 37(a), granting the plaintiff the right to annul the tenure.
Argument: The plaintiff argued that under the amended Section 37, they were entitled to annul the tenure as the defendants failed to fulfill legal criteria for protection.
Statute: Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885; Estate Sale Regulations, Section 37.
Rules: The decision analyzed whether the defendants’ tenure was protected under the amended provisions of the Bengal Tenancy Act.
Precedent: The court reaffirmed that an estate sold for arrears is free from encumbrances unless statutory exceptions apply.
Ratio of the Decision: The ruling emphasized that encumbrances do not transfer on estates sold for arrears, unless they meet legal exceptions.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of the plaintiff, granting them the right to annul the tenure since it did not meet the requirements for protection under the amended Act.

Case Name: Beni Madhab Shaw Alias Benia Vs. State of West Bengal
Issue Presented: Whether the petitioner was lawfully detained under the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner was accused of theft from railway wagons, leading to service disruption. He was detained under the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.
Ruling by Lower Court: Not explicitly stated.
Argument: The petitioner argued that his detention order was improperly made under the Essential Commodities Act, thereby violating his legal rights.
Rules: The case examined whether the detention order aligned with legal and constitutional requirements under the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.
Precedent: The ruling emphasized the importance of proper procedure in preventive detention cases to avoid violations of constitutional rights.
Ratio of the Decision: The judgment underscored the necessity of due process in preventive detention to uphold constitutional protections.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the petitioner’s detention was unlawful.

Case Name: Raghu Raj Singh Rousha Vs. M/S. Shivam Sundaram Promoters (P) Ltd. & Anr.
Respondent: M/S. Shivam Sundaram Promoters (P) Ltd. & Anr.
Issue Presented: Whether the High Court could pass an order under Sections 397 and 401 of the CrPC without hearing the accused.
Facts of the Case: The petitioner filed a complaint under Section 200 of the CrPC, alleging fraud and breach of contract.
Ruling by Lower Court: The lower court refused to order an investigation under Section 156(3) due to a lack of direct evidence.
Argument: The petitioner argued that their right to be heard was violated by the High Court passing an order without their presence.
Statute: Sections 397, 401, and 200 of the CrPC; related provisions of the IPC concerning fraud and criminal breach of trust.
Rules: The case explored whether revisional jurisdiction could be exercised without adhering to natural justice principles.
Precedent: The ruling highlighted the necessity of providing both parties an opportunity to be heard before decisions are made in revisional matters.
Ratio of the Decision: The decision reiterated the importance of due process in revisional jurisdiction, ensuring natural justice is upheld.
Ruling: The Supreme Court ruled that the High Court violated natural justice principles by passing the order without hearing the accused.
